8ymlt8ygqjoV18IXVIcT8A.review_text: We made reservations on a Saturday night.  I was soo excited to try this place after hearing all the hype! The restaurant was pretty empty when we arrived.  However, I couldn't believe how slow the service was! We got the AYCE shabu with beef and chicken.  The beef was nice and thinly cut, as we saw someone standing there cutting the beef with the nifty machine! However, the quality of the meat was okay.  It was not as marbled as other places.  The chicken just tasted normal, like pieces of boiled chicken.  It was cool that they give you three different sauces to dip everything in.  The vegetables were okay, but lacked some variety.  It is pretty cool how each person gets their own pot, although I feel like I have to yell across to talk to my friends.  Overall, everything was okay until I had to keep on flagging down the waiters.  Service is super bad here.  It's all you can eat, but if you can't find your waiters and get more food, what's the point of that?!?! :P

xIpbYrn8IGcNZz0Tj4XFIg.review_text: had my bday party here 2 years in a row.... steve the mgr accomodated me and 35 friends.... yes a party of 36 with less than 5 hours notice... can't get any crazier and rowdier than this.... all my friends had a great time, the food was nice and fresh... and oh how i love the beef, perfectly sliced so thin to cook in 30 seconds or less.... we all did ayce and aycead.... boy was that bill huge... but in the end we all had fun and left full...

TUVaya-VY5WmKHIsv0sx0Q.review_text: I live around the corner from here and am kicking myself for not coming here sooner. I went with a friend before a movie on a Tuesday around 6pm and it was empty, easy to get a table. Service was super quick and attentive. It was our first time experiencing Shabu and our waitress was happy to explain how everything worked. Each person got their own pot to boil their meat, veggies, etc. I had chicken and my Friend had beef and we shared pot stickers. it was SO much to eat, we could never have done all you can eat!. The meat was fresh and healthy. They even have a freezer with the mean showcased as you walk in so that you know it is of quality. The meal is super healthy and filling. You order a meat dish, or combo of meats, then on the side you get noodles, veggies, cabbage, tofu, etc to add to the stew pot. You will not leave hungry of feeling greasy. Thus having some sake or beer with your meal doesn't make you feel guilty. I would think this would be a great place for groups. they have long banquet tables that can accommodate up to 20 people where each person can still have their own cooking pot.   If you are looking for a good, healthy, filling meal on a cold day, or a place to take a group, I would recommend happy Shabu Shabu. I can't wait to go back. However, next time I'll pass on the chicken, it just tasted like boring boiled chicken even with all the dipping sauces. The beef is definitely the way to go.

r4m3F6H2AFC6f3Vtb1xzLg.review_text: 3.5  stars  This place lives up to its name on a Friday night. Reasons to celebrate causes many to drink with friends and even neighboring tables. Price point is similar to other shabu joints and service is good.  I prefer their meat to Kufu-ya on Geary. I like to mix the hot and ponzu sauce together.....would prefer them to have fresher condiments (finer minced garlic, get rid of the ill tasting chilli oil, and put some spicy daikon out).  Great alternative to Mum's or Shabuzen and can accommodate large parties.

ul7BUIe1U7JnrX13C01JWw.review_text: Shabu Shabu AYCE!!   Came here on a Friday night and made reservations. If one person gets AYCE then everyone else has to, but it's not that expensive and in my eyes well worth it. Broth for the soup was good and there's even an option to have the spicy portion on the side.  Meat is fresh and plentiful. They always fill up your plate when they notice it's empty. Service is excellent! The owner comes around and chats and even drinks shots with you. I'd definetly come here again!

3fExHy4rllL9wPFlDxrN4Q.review_text: I've been here multiple times, and you can always count on Happy Shabu Shabu to be consistent.  Although, I guess that isn't too hard when the restaurant doesn't have to cook any of your food!  I keep coming back to this place for the great all-you-can-eat  (and all-you-can-drink for $12 more) deal.  It's the perfect way to start off a fun, alcohol-fueled night.   I'm taking one star away because of the seating  - the tables are separated by an aisle that the employees use to control your fire and to serve you, which makes it difficult for you to talk to the person/people across from you.

guQk2FYdm_4lU56JPnCIcw.review_text: We went there as a party of 11 people. In contradictory to one of the reviewers mentioned, half of our party had "all you can eat/drink" and some had just one plater, the place didn't make us all select the same.  Food was great, drinks kept coming, service was five stars! we even got some extra shots :) My only complain can be that I ate waaaaaayyyy too much :) But this one on me ;) So next time I will order 1 plate for me :))   This place made me fell in love with Shabu, and I will definitely  come back!

_KKFgmyaYrW3EdhAjTfQKQ.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu cant touch Shabu Shabu House in LA! without a doubt! the rad thing about this joint is that its food is up to par and the atmosphere. the not so rad thing about this joint is that the service sucks. i waited 2 hrs to get seated and served for a party of 6! lame. if you want all you can eat and all you can drink this place is for you.

XnLOt51lFAi24wU8DppuSw.review_text: Always good times with here crew that runs place, Ken and Lamb. This shabu place is cheaper than most and just as good. AYCE for $23 and AYCE + all you can drink for $35 when most places charge $35 for JUST AYCE. How can you go wrong?

GyYInrWOVwPEqECKOC9T3g.review_text: Came here for my bday with a party of 8.  The staff here are really nice but all their super strict rules are pretty annoying.  I understand all AYCE shabu places are like this but it doesn't make it less annoying.  The one nice thing about this compared to competitors is they allow some people in the party to choose all you can drink and some not where as Shabu House foreces you to do all or none.  They are very strict on the 2 hour limit and that starts as soon as you order food or drink- so if your party doesnt come on time and someone wants a drink while they wait- tick tock.... However, being a beast who inhales food, I would say that 2 hours is more than enough time for me as I was stuffed to death by 1 hour and 15 min- granted I didn't really chew but inhaled all I could inhale :)  The food here is very good and they are pretty generous and attentive in refilling our plates as we get low.  What I don't like about the restaurant is the way the tables are set.  For big parties, if you have 8 people, you sit in a table section where you can each have your own pot.  However, the tables are really far away from each other leaving a huge gap in the middle for waiters to walk between to turn on and off the pot.  So you will have to shout far and loud to talk to your friends or limited to only talking to people who are directly next to you.  If you have over 8 ppl in your party, they'll seat you in the same place and some people will have to share pots.  Lastly, they have a spicy sauce you can add to your broth to give it a little kick, but they dont have that out so you'll have to ask for chili pepper sauce.

tfg1Nhwx94Y4GdQHLVawbw.review_text: If you're just looking for a rambunctious Shabu Shabu experience full of food and booze, hit up Mum's. if not, this is a good place to do all you can eat hot pot in a civilized manner. Each person has their own pot which is a great benefit especially for those  who don't like to share pots. You get full control over your broth flavors and limit saliva contributions from your party. Food quality is good but limited like the other places, just beef, chicken and veggies. Service is really slow with one person running the place although it is not a large restaurant by any means. If Shabu House is too far of a drive, this location in Pac Heights may be a good alternative.

f81Y2EzuRqefayCrL1Ra3Q.review_text: I think Happy Shabu Shabu is almost there but not quite it.  Their meat is fresh and marbled really well but I think for the price that you pay for AYCE (~$25/person), their selection is small and their broth is lacking in flavor.  The three sauces that you get definitely make up for its flavor issues but it's not anywhere I dream about going or really think about...  All in all, I wouldn't reject it if my friend wanted to come here for their birthdays but I wouldn't be enthralled either.

kLLXE4ziLtVIyyYfqUL2kw.review_text: :( We used to love this place.  I've eaten at most of the Shabu joints in San Francisco.  Despite the awkward seating arrangements (you can only sit 4 in row all facing the same way, or 2 in a row, separated from the rest of your party), we used to prefer Happy.  They offered minced garlic and green onions to add to your hotpot, as well as a spicy miso paste.  The all-you-can eat is more expensive than Cafe Mum, but the quality of the meat seemed a little higher and the vegetable plate was fresher and more extensive.  I do remember being a bit annoyed last time we went because nobody in your party can have the all-you-can-eat option if anyone is ordering seafood. Tonight's experience means I will never go back.  Upon sitting down, we were told again - no all-you-eat option, as someone is ordering the seafood.  Oh well.   Let's start with a beer and a glass of white wine.  Nope, all out of white wine!  In addition, they were also out of the miso paste - and rice!  I mean really?  You are out of rice?  the staple of EVERY meal on the menu?  The meat quality was still ok, but if you have to buy it by the plate it is EXPENSIVE and the seafood was frozen solid. I guess we will go back to Shabusen (not all you can eat, but good quality).

jNpquKQ-lZNzj2HXd_4PKw.review_text: I feel like with shabu shabu places, since you basically cook your own stuff, the food is pretty standard.  It's all about the experience.  I wouldn't say my experience here was horrible, but it was not enjoyable to say the least.  I had a large group, and there was another large group too.  Right when we got in, we saw that one of our large groups had to sit outside.  It was windy and cold that day.  Thankfully, it was the other group that got the 'cold treatment' and we were say inside.  They looked pretty pissed though, can't imagine what their yelp review might look like.  Then came dinner.  Naturally, with big parties, some people come late, but for the most part, a lot of my group was there.  However, that didn't stop the manager from constantly pestering us.  The odd thing though was the he wasn't flat out saying things to us, it was very passive aggressive.  Like if he wanted us to wrap up, he would tell us that there's a group coming in an hour.  So it's like he was implying we should hurry, but not flat out telling us.  He was also kind of rude about it.  Be careful having large parties here too.  It's a pretty small place, so if you have a large group, you'll no doubt have some awkward seating arrangements.  Luckily, by the end of dinner, I was a little buzzed, so I didn't care about any of that.  This place isn't the worst, but it could certainly do better.  I looked at the other yelp reviews, and I'm not the only person complaining about the tacky service that was received.

_focy66G85KXrIHmhfXGMg.review_text: Food: beef quality was terrible. Sauces were basic. Overall, not impressive shabu shabu place, even for the average prices.  Ambience: This place is not good for groups of 4. You have to be seated in 1 row, or if you want to be across from each other, you'll be about 6 feet away from your friends because of a gap between tables. This is terrible for conversation.  Restaurant policy: ridiculous. We had 4 ppl total. 3 of us wanted all you can eat, and 1 person was a vegetarian. They refused to let her order vegetarian only dish and insisted she pay for the all you can eat meat price because all 4 of us had to do it. The restaurant was almost empty, so its not like you couldn't figure out if we were trying to cheat them of $10. So we asked them to split the bill (we were sitting 6 ft away from each other after all)... 2 would do ala carte so the other 2 can do all you can eat. They refused. So we all did ala carte. They lost an automatic $30 in revenue by not letting 3 of us upgrade. And it turns out that no one wanted more than 1 plate of meat anyways, because the quality was so terrible. What we should have done was walked out from the onset.   Will never go here again, and would never recommend this place. For the food, ambience and service, I'd recommend shabu house or anywhere besides here. Btw, most shabu shabu places offer all you can drink/eat options.

P9F8WA_BPbRymwawWwYM-Q.review_text: It's really $35 for all you can eat AND drink. The food and drink is good. If you need more of a reason to try this place, consider kicking yourself in the shabu shabu

Sz6JeWg0AaiT__VQjwvYEg.review_text: Yummy shabu on a cold New Year's Eve night.

gKQbQckZ8tIHUd4ghza66g.review_text: Great Food, Great Service, and alot of fun!  I visited last night with 3 friends.  We did have a table for 4, which is actualy two tables facing each other with a gap in between to allow the waitress easy access to control the stoves and to serve.  The distance from table mates did make conversation a little difficut, but not impossible as others have mentioned.  You just have to speak a little louder!  We all had the all-you-can-eat and drink dinner, for $35 each.  Very well worth it!  The waitress (Lynn) could not have been friendlier.  Sensing we were not experienced Shabu Shabu'ers, she explained everything with a very cheerful smile.  The food was great!  Veggies were farm stand fresh, and the chicken and beef both very tasty and fresh!  Very little fat in the beef, and none in the skinless chicken breast pieces/  Others have mentioned that the broth consisted of boiling water.  That was not the case last night, the broth was miso soup, and had a nice flavor.  Our waitress helped us season the broth with chili peppers, some kind of pepper spice, onions and garlic.  I kind of wanted to eat the broth, but didn't.  Our waitress was very attentive, always ready to bring more beer, meat and veggies.  She also brought us both hot and cold sake, but none of us are really sake drinkers.  Towards the end of the evening, when the place was clearing out, our waitress spent some time talking, laughing and sharing drinks with us.  It was a wonderful adventure, and we will certainly return!

3jyJ7VIRuKiZDr6WwAvovg.review_text: So I've been here twice and both times we opted for the $35 all you can eat all you can drink. TOTALLY WORTH IT!! The first time we went for my friends birthday. By the end of the night he was pretty much chanting ONLY MEAT! ( I guess he didn't want to eat his veggies) and the dude drank so much he lost the birthday present I gave him. I was not happy about that. But was happy with the food. SOO YUMMIE. You can just pick up the beef with your chop sticks and swirl it in the hot water and the meat cooks in like a min. The veggies are good too and of course the fresh noodles. If you want more of whatever: veggies, tofu, noodles, or meal they'll bring it out to you on a small plate. Which is nice and it makes you feel less wasteful. By the end of the night I promise that you'll make friends with whoever else is in the restaurant. It never fails.   The only bad thing is that you have to make reservations. Both times I was there they turned people away.  Even if the place looks empty the tables are probably reserved.

9TU1CISaeQWVZuL2hMQSUg.review_text: Was tempted to eat some meat so i decided to try this place since the All you can eat Shabu was $23 per person. Went with a group of 2 around 5:30pm and it was dead empty. I believe i saw the owner sitting outside before i walked in so i thought to myself... probably no business at this time. As i walked in i saw a television and lots of empty tables! Yeah for empty tables! Only took me 1 minute to figure out where to sit, since there's so much to choose from. Sat down ordered and chilled to the korean background music, while watching the NBA on tv.   As most all you can eat place can't really have a group with all you can eat, and non all you can eat, unless separated. Service was 100% since we were the only ones there. Each person has their own pot to cook their food in and 3 different type of sauce. Along with a dish of veggies and noodles. Only had to type of meat, Chicken and Beef, so i decided to try some chicken.   I was hoping for some rice, since the last shabu i had a few years back served rice, but apparently i didn't get any. The first 2 plates of beef was really good, since it was thinly sliced. After the 3rd plate, i felt that the meat started to taste a bit flavorless or maybe unfresh? All i can say is it didn't have the same feeling as the first 2 dish i ate earlier.   I ate about 4 plates of beef, and was looking at the owner and the waitress. Based on their expression of their face, it almost looked as if their saying...."How can that little guy eat so much?" Since i finished the first 2 plates in about 20 mins or so. I believed i was there eating for about almost 1 1/2 hours.  Overall i would say the service for today was 90% good~! since the waitress occasionally kept coming and asking if we needed anything; considering there was no one in there but us. I was sad cause i didn't get any rice! xD  Also my soup changed color after the 3rd plate, probably thats why my beef tasted crappy. Needed new Soup!...  It would be better if they had more variety of meat to choose from, like Sheep! that would make me coming back for more!, but nope. I thought it was funny how a random person came in asking if they can use the bathroom, but was refused since it was "customers only" and that guy just took a piss outside the trashcan or something.

F262q88zc7zsdEeNCzcA0A.review_text: I was so excited when I stumbled upon this place. My boyfriend and I were in the city to see Yeasayer at the Fillmore and planned on eating dinner in sf. We had no clue where to go, and figured we'd find a place while on our way to the venue. We walked by happy shabu shabu and were excited to find a shabu shabu place when we didn't know what to expect. The quality of the meat is nothing compared to shabuway in mt. view, but thats because they use kobe instead of a regular cut. I was really excited by all their sauces and their miso broth to cook the food in. Also their vegetable plate seemed a lot more complete than what I'm used to (Bok-choy, cabbage, tofu, enoki, shitake, carrot, scallion, udon, yam noodle). So although the meat wasn't the greatest the sauces and veggies were superb! I'd probably eat here again if I was near the Flllmore for the show.

-Hxvjz-t5ttsuH6H1osA4A.review_text: IH's choice for bday dinner locale.  AMBIANCE: Not the most happenin' spot on a Saturday night during prime dinner time (7:30pm).  The few patrons who were there were quiet pairs of friends who quickly ate and left.  We were the largest and loudest group there (13p).  The seating plan is quite odd-- diners sit facing other groups with a aisle in between (I guess its meant for the staff to walk in between and deliver items/turn on the burners?).  Awkwardddd.  This also meant that our large group was squished into a space meant for two parties of 4, with a huge dividing aisle between us.  SERVICE: The servers (one was the owner?) were nice enough, but practically impossible to flag down.  They also have the strictest rules/ordering policies that I've ever encountered at a shabu shabu/AYCE restaurant.  If you want AYCE, your entire party must order it, no exceptions.  The staff said that if half our party (seated across the aisle) wanted AYCD, that was possible, but if the other half opted out they would not be able to order ANY drinks.  Did they expect us to sneakily chuck drinks across that massive canyon of an aisle!?  FOOD: We sampled AYCE beef/chicken/veggies.  Standard ponzu and sesame dipping sauces, along with a spicy chili sauce.  The meats were quite tough, despite a large amount of fattiness in the beef.  The chicken was horrible-- sooooo dry/tough.  The selection of veggies for the AYCE vegetarian option looked nice, but came with the same price tag as for the meat AYCE, which seemed unfairly hefty.   OVERALL: 2 stars sums it up-- Meh. I've experienced better.  Would much rather dine at Shabu House or even Mum's.  Will not be returning.

bXjywxQEN-TPs99IG2s6EA.review_text: This place is right in my neck of the woods....  too bad it sux.  Overpriced yuckage.  I won't come back unless I'm desperate, since it is right down stairs.    Choriya on Clement is much, much better all around.

jCcJC5v4D88u7F45zdgWdA.review_text: If you are a germaphobe, this is the perfect place. You get your own pot :)   Sauce was ok though. They do not refill the broth so when you get down to the end, it's super salty. Meat was good. They cut it right when you order.   Either by order or all you can eat.

JITevzyEgskIJc6sgOyEgw.review_text: I sold back some clothes so I could go eat here.  In terms of shabu shabu I think it's great.  It's pricey but I found most shabu places are.  The interior is immaculate but the place tends to cater towards large groups.  Either way, I was able to go in as a two some and get a corner table that fit us both.  The beef was so yummy I asked for a second half order.  The chef even agreed to charge me half since they don't have half orders on the menu.  I'd say the all you can shabu and sake is probably worth it.  Alone I could drink about $40 worth of sake, the cheap stuff too, so I'm already ahead of the game by $5.  I do recommend not getting just chicken, maybe its because I love beef but it takes longer to cook and isn't as tender.  Oh and I don't think the broth is really broth.  They really need to offer miso, spicy or regular.  That makes the shabu!!

S1W-_Ghqr3eVaytqQSfz5g.review_text: Caution! Although as posted Birthdays are free, don't confuse this for a good meal to eat before a night of heavy drinking and debauchery. After spending $40  here and eating as much glorified soup (because that's all this really is) as capacity allows, You'll be hungry 2 hours later upon the majority of the broth leaving your body. This food also doesn't safeguard your stomach much from alcohol consumption though you think it would since you feel full as we've all experienced  with pizza. Over All service was great, Beer was forthcoming but despite that it is once again really just bowls of soup - meat being boiled in a not exactly flavorful broth. Ok date place but bday parties should seek out a hearty meal.

vRziAXWI72nOFWNml4ldMA.review_text: Went here with like 30 people for a 30th birthday. We sat outside in the front that was partitioned off with a gate but it was right along side the sidewalk so it was kinda weird since passerby's would stare while we were eating. But that didn't matter. All you can eat AND ALL YOU CAN DRINK. We drank sake and beer to our hearts content. 30 people and my friend's 30th birthday and about 10 hot pots goin you can imagine it was a good thing we were outside cuz it would been steaming inside.   The food itself was really good. The meat was fresh and the veges were as well. We were loud and rowdy bunch and the owner Steve put up with our antics and was totally cool with our group.  We're already talking about going back but in a smaller group.

nvdmAIrhRCu5n2ro-uEyhg.review_text: Last night was the best night of my life. From the moment I walked in I was entranced. Your smell, your taste, the way you filled me up. You came right on time and filled me up just right. You were like a feast for all of my senses...Last night i got drunk on you and I am still hungover. Happy Shabu Shabu. I love you ! I really and truly do ;^)

A0Y4dUb2LOM6n0kewefUXg.review_text: Wow, I bow in reverence to this fine take on the hedonistic ritual of the Shabu-Shabu.  Great little selection on the served platter of meat, veg, and seafood.  The scallops were huuuge!  I liked the Korean twist on the sauces and broth.  BYOB d(-_-)b  I'd recommend friendly groupings of 4 or 8 to allow for facing off in 2 opposing rows (reservation recommended for weekends).  I'll def be back!

KAU0uc4Ff_RNfJ_3_BKgug.review_text: I've been to this shabu shabu establishment countless times, since the opening of the restaurant. The food has consistently stayed fresh and my experience has been consistently pleasant here.   The food:  I normally order either the beef entree shabu shabu or the beef all you can eat shabu shabu. First of all, the ingredients are very fresh (from what my amateur palate can tell) including the vegetables (bok choy, spinach, napa cabbage, shitake mushrooms, carrots, tofu) and angus beef (well-marbled, not too lean (which becomes even leaner if u boil it!), but not too fatty either). I've been to Cafe Mum's before and I felt that happy happy's quality of beef was higher. In terms of the entree portions, I think it may be on the light side, especially for those coming in very hungry. Because of this fact, when i come here hungry, i prefer to opt for the all you can eat. I think the all you can eat option is a good value (~25) especially since the combined price of a beef entree + extra plate of beef comes out to the same price!   The service:  There isn't too much to say under this category since shabu shabu is more of a self-service affair. Sometimes i felt the service was understaffed, though i would wholely understand from their point of view why they wouldn't staff many more waitresses for a self-service cuisine. Despite being understaffed, however, when I did ask for something, the waitress/waiter got it to me promptly. I guess one gripe that i have with the staff is that they come over to your stove often to adjust the heat setting. Sounds great, but there were times where i wanted the water boiling more and would adjust it myself manually and the waitress would then come over and readjust it! Annoying haha.   The setting:  First of all, i greatly appreciate the fact that happy shabu shabu provides every customer with their OWN pot (as opposed to cafe mum's). It makes the dining experience much less stressful when you don't have to fight for the pot. Despite that first positive, however, i really wish this place arranged the counters in a better way. It is designed where every pair of counter space is divided in the center by a walkway so that the waitress can come over and adjust the heat of your pot. The problem is, though, that if you have a companion sitting across from you, they are pretty far from you, making it seem like you have to yell to talk to them. In other words, if you want to be able to feel like you're sitting close or next to your friends, you would have to have them sit adjacent to you on your left or right side. There can be no decent face to face arrangement in this restaurant.   Overall, i always have a satisfying dining experience here. The food is really good and i think the best shabu shabu ive had in the city so far. The service is lacking at times, but it's forgiveable (they are not rude or stuck-up or anything like that). I recommend this restaurant =).

mPOm-t-ugkcjpbZVTw0UGg.review_text: Good shabu place, but not fantastic. Ingredients were ok, but I have been to a number of shabu places in japan and this place can't compete.  I did agree with one of the other yelpers about the layout. It would be way better if people could face eachother to talk. I would have rather been looking at my girlfriend than the other party on the other side of the room. Also, the communal pot is a more fun way to go. The one last suggestion is to turn the broth into a soup afterwards. They often do this in japan and Orbison one of the best parts of the meal.   All in all, decent food, and I would go back until I find a better one.

OeWgkeEytk5DSfO0nLB89g.review_text: 2 stars unfortunately...  Their Shabu Shabu is not authentic at all. First off, the authentic Shabu Shabu broth should be clear and seaweed based, but theirs is miso based. We never have Miso based broth for Shabu Shabu in Japan. And their sesame sauce is too watery and has no flavor.  If you are not looking for the authentic Shabu Shabu, this place might work to you, but it is not for me.

YokdbgV1rurLp3wG0tUgAg.review_text: 4 stars for prices (get the all you can eat and drink for about $26)  3 stars for service (we wondered several times if the server had forgotten about us)  1 star for ambiance. This place was a frat/douche magnet. The adjacent table was a huge party of 30-something drunky, golf-playing, bro-bro, douches who ruined the ambiance for everyone in the restaurant. Management didn't seem to be bothered by these people's public drunkenness and obnoxiousness. In fact, they took part in the debauchery.   But the shabu was fresh and cheap. Maybe you get what you pay for? Just don't expect a nice date night out of this place.

fXKRTax3LU5mLat_-Z13zQ.review_text: i came here for my birthday so we had a large group and sat outside. there are flies there but it was tolerable because they have a bug zapper and heater. the food was good. =]

5fpCfqVq1Nm2YafJ3VHU8g.review_text: Delicious, simple food, good service, so much fun to go w/ friends. The seating arrangements are a bit awkward for parties of three but it's still nice.

Dk5EPbo1T7F6YA-S2_ZOiw.review_text: If I could bathe in shabu shabu, I would.  I've been here numerous times and had a great time each and every time.  The service is kind of funny, its usually a bunch of teenage girls that try to rush you in and out, but I kind of like them. They just want to go in the back and check their phones.  Its super cheap for what you get, I always leave thinking I ate too much, but in reality I just ate a huge plate of veggies.  They give you a wide array of stuff to choose from and the experience is just fun no matter what you get.  I've had both the veggie platter and the beef.  Both very good.  But the star is the sauces they give you.  I'd like to plan a party here at some point, think it would be a good birthday place or pre-party venue.

muXmjGeUVRphngjtO37IHw.review_text: (UN) Happy Shabu Shabu.....Since I can't give zero stars it gets a one. So, if making reservations only to have your table given away 30 minutes before your reservation time is your thing then this is the place for you!  We made reservations for a party of 8 at 8:30.  We drove up from Santa Cruz for my birthday dinner.  We got to the restaurant at 8:25 only to be told our table had been given away at 8:00!!  The manager told us that he called us to confirm the reservation and since we didn't get the call he gave our table away!  These reservations were made by my husband weeks in advance.  I also emailed them and my sister called 2 days prior.  The manager even said "you're the birthday party-right?" So he knew that we were coming.  Thank you for making my birthday dinner very UNhappy!!

4hkDcOpUbpkvkKOIcMkS1A.review_text: My boyfriend and I were really excited about eating at a Shabu Shabu restaurant because they have nothing like this in Austin and while the food was good, there are a lot of other areas that need attention.  My boyfriend had ordered the "all you can eat" beef shabu shabu and they told him he could only order it if I ordered it too.  I wasn't too hungry, but I knew he wanted it so I was pretty much forced to order this as well.  I thought this move made them look really cheap and I bet this hurts them more than it helps.  Although the miso broth was a tad salty, everything tasted delicious overall.  There is one thing I have to mention that I found really weird though.  Growing up, I'm use to eating my shabu shabu with a raw egg, but when we asked for some, we were told that they didn't have eggs?  I thought that was strange.  Also, they sat us right by the door and they left the door open because a lot of people were in the establishment, so we had cold air blowing on us the entire time.  Not exactly what I would call A+ service.  While the food was good, I would probably try to go somewhere else next time I'm craving Shabu Shabu in San Francisco.

m2h-3Hscogycjf68nbABvg.review_text: This is the seriously the WORST Shabu Shabu ever!!!  The restaurant caught my attention because of the ad of "ALL YOU CAN EAT Shabu Shabu."  But when we found out if one of our friends wants to get the "ALL YOU CAN EAT", the rest of the party members need to get the "ALL YOU CAN EAT", we were kind of disappointed. The funny part is the waitress kept telling us that we cannot sit separately! Since only two of our friends wanted to order "all you can eat", it made the rest of us (other 6 people) are required to order the "all you can eat." The waitress were kind of annoying, especially the attitude were bad.   Luckily for them, we were all tired and starving; we still decided to "corporate" with their rule....   The foods were decent, but the sauces are insanely bad!! Let me address it again!! ALL three sauces for the Shabu Shabu are really bad!! The sesame sauces are extremely water-downed, the chili sauces are very salty, the soy sauces are at least eatable...seriously, these are the sauces for people who don't know/ never had Shabu Shabu!

6XCZoufB_S-sY6vsxMGd8Q.review_text: Came here last night after an event at Yoshi's.  I really appreciate the individual pots.  There are a lot of better Shabu places in the city.  Mums and even this place on 34th and Geary called Ku Fuya.  I personally don't like Shabu house on Geary but there seems to be a great buzz over that place.  I still can't figure out why???  I like their home made hot sauce.  I think they make it fresh here.  You know what the bad thing about Shabu Shabu is?  There are just so many of them to compare them to.  If you have a choice and trust me, in San Francisco, you have a lot of choices, this restaurant is not going to pop out at you.

PtTZf3VF_JwSKf-rkhuvRA.review_text: This is prob my go-to all-you-can-eat/drink shabu shabu place when I don't feel like driving to Shabu House in the Richmond. It's nice and clean, meat is decent quality, and hey - I get my own bottle of sake! The only dings are that I wish they gave all-you-can-eat noodles with the veggies (bc really, noodles are not that expensive) and the seating is really weird - bc everyone gets their own pot, if you come with a party of 3+ you'll either be yelling at each other across two sets of tables or seated along a long table. Also, they charge you a couple dollars if you don't finish your food.

PFxDw_dWjzhykkFg6nFLlg.review_text: Ughhhh!!! (sigh)  the food is good, the service is great. BUT one night, i took my friend out there to have some good time. it was closing already, but the waitress asked us to take our time. right when she said it, a man came over (who i think was the owner) and rudely said "we are closing now, i'm giving you 2 minutes to leave"!!! i felt like i wanna flip the table over! the waitress was soooo embarrassed by what the guy said, she apologized and smiled and looked down the whole time. it was not "happy" shabu shabu for me! boo you!

P-CRYltpvp4aABRctIZWtg.review_text: For the bay area, I was greatly disappointed by this common culinary practice found commonly in southern California (excluding Asian-culture deprived San Diego) and smaller cities like Portland.  I have attempted to dine here twice with friends unsuccessfully because it closed before 9:30 PM on Sunday and not opened during lunch. Finally I've made it here but with great disappointment.  First of, it's a trap. It's Cantonese people operating an Japanese style restaurant without the grace and substance to back it up. But they did overcharge wholeheartedly.  It's like going to kindergarten here, an entry level service. It offered individual big pot "in" the counter top. Nothing communal here. One had to get a portable stove to use on the dining table.  The menu was so limited with chicken and beef as meat choice, some tofu, vegetables, and noodles. It's much cheaper to get the combo for $15, than ordering individual items. The quantity was anemic by $15.  There was a choice for all-you-can-eat: $22 (just beef and chicken) or $30 for meats and seafood. Too much for this simple restaurant.  There was no alternate choice for broth or sauce. The only pluses are clean and fresh foods. Service was so-so.  So diners, it's too simplistic for a hot pot experience. Go a small distance and you may find much better choices, like on Geary, or near SF Airport, or in Richmond.

DRPMOcCHjtEjlfLyulvMNw.review_text: As many yelpers have said, it's a 2 Starr overall.   Came here on a Wednesday night with 3 friends. This place was so dead and it was literally the 4 of us.   Yes, it's nice that you get your own pot so you can do whatever you want. However the beef was horrible.. Beef tasted like cardboard.. Bubble gum.. It was really really disappointing!

swjufuHxKjn1tCnZuyxkYQ.review_text: The interior layout of the restaurant is a bit odd. The tables are long and rectangular with space in-between for the server to adjust heat as needed. (Each setting includes it's own individual cooking station.) If you go with a group of people your options are to either sit side-by-side in a row or sit across from one another and yell back and forth over the ~7 foot space. If you choose the former option (side-by-side) then you may find yourself directly facing another party at the opposite table which is a little awkward.  The food is average. Ingredients seemed relatively fresh, however I found the soup base to be slightly bland. While the food wasn't necessarily offensive, it wasn't exciting nor authentic.

gGi67233NwosdE4J1FNb_A.review_text: Was an awesome meal, and the deal can't be beat.  For those complaining about the broth being "water" - that's why they give you about 5 different seasonings on the table - to build your own broth.  Start with those, and then add the vegetables to build an even richer broth.  As you cook the meat the broth will become richer and richer.

7banvXk1-gJyrU3nbzJN8w.review_text: I love this place!  I bring friends here all the time.  The key is to order the Kobe Beef shabu, which is about $17 for a platter (each platter comes with the meat, veggies, dipping sauces and your own pot).  The difference between the Kobe and the regular meat is HUGE, and I don't know why they don't advertise the kobe!  I stay away on weekends because the all you can drink crowd is obnoxious, but on a regular weekend night, you shouldn't have a problem getting a seat and enjoying a yummy meal.

7S6geHhDFDexPPl611n9jQ.review_text: Affordable all you can eat and friendly service. The shabu is not the best quality but if you are in for a quick shabu fix, this place will do it for you.

Xjxrab7B42JhXAq4oiJd4A.review_text: I like this place. I'd rather go elsewhere, but they do have AYCE/drink with decent service.  The people here are friendly and very tolerant of the many drunken people that pass through this establishment. Service is great. I've actually had shots with the manager before!  The food quality is decent. Not melt-in-your-mouth as it is at Shabu Shabu House in Little Tokyo (Los Angeles), but hey, you get what you pay for.  The one thing I really don't like about this place is that everyone gets his/her own pot. Some people love that about this place, but I've usually gone with a party of 6-8, so it can get really awkward when you're shouting across the room just to 'talk' to someone.  Recommended, but there are better places. Also, parking is a pain in that area, which also discourages me from going. Don't park in the Safeway lot because you WILL get towed.

iYXGmvMXSACfcUKtSFR19Q.review_text: I think the atmosphere was better than the food. Great service, great time. The food wasn't bad, I'm just not a big meat eater and the main courses are mostly meat.   It was an interesting experience to cook our own food.  Glad I went but I'm not sure if I'd go back.

vqZCDJ8RpOU6nPJhUWi2jw.review_text: This was the first Shabu place I've ever eaten at, and the food was excellent. The broth had good flavor and the sauces, though a little thin, were tasty. Had a FULL stomach and a big Tsingtao for about 20 bucks. You can't beat that in San Fran!

aogitBr6Agn05REca5LArA.review_text: This is one of my favorite places to eat in the city.  We're practically there every weekend! As a huge shabu shabu fan, I have to say this place is 5 stars! The beef is very fresh and they give you the perfect amount of veggies.  My favorite part about this place is that they give you an extra dipping sauce that's so yummy.  The service here is beyond excellent.  The waitresses come and scoop out the junk in your hot pot for you, and they sometimes assemble your dipping sauce for you.  And, the price is reasonable.  There's nothing bad I can say about Happy Shabu Shabu.  We absolutely love it!

a3nmcUKCrqYXxwS-XwYCSQ.review_text: Shabu? I had no clue what it was till my friend told me I should eat here for dinner and to come with an empty stomach. So basically it's like a personal hot pot in front of me. We ordered all you can eat deal which includes beef and chicken. I only order beef that night. It was thinly sliced, right in front of me. They also give you a dish of noodles and veggies to throw into your miso broth. you also get 3 different types of dipping sauce to choose from. Everything was very tasty and fresh. Service was very good and attentive and made sure I was enjoying my meal and boy I was. I ended up eating 2 plates of veggies/noodles and 3 plates of beef. When you are just starving and want a meal to fill you up this is the place to come to. A little pricey but think about it you're paying for good quality food. I will definitely be coming back.

Z9pfNGaep9G3N8jEKtUrnA.review_text: If you've never been to a Shabu Shabu before, you should definitely Google around to find out how exactly you're supposed to eat this stuff.  I introduced my friend Peter to his first Shabu Shabu experience here, and he kept trying all sorts of things.  After throwing all his vegetables in the pot at once, he poured all his dipping sauces in.  Then he concluded that leaving the meat in the water for a long duration would infuse the soup with flavor -- ruining his meat.  Sigh. Why do the pretty ones always have to be so dumb?

cyP2lSmvg992LxoqfO6ZeQ.review_text: Great place to stuff your mouth and tummy! Unlimited plates of thin slice beef, pork, or chicken. Very good service. Well worth the money!

frGQmQWy2iwGZcOLlfsAVg.review_text: Please visit Jon to experience a warm welcome and warm broth for an amazing Shabu Shabu experience. This restaurant was great for service and style. The beef is incredible. Highly recommend this restaurant.

jLzs0c0paLBQgIlu6aVUOg.review_text: we had the all you-can-eat with drinks for about 35 a person.  between 3 girls we had 6 plates of meat and 4 plates of veggies.   the customer services was awesome, always brought what we need right of way.  everything was very fresh.  def will go back again!!

6ZR7HuUpHk_NQNs0dT0oLg.review_text: I guess they're trying to compete with Shabu House cause now they offer their broth with flavor! And you can get it spicy!  BUUUUT now they don't give you dumplings with your all you can eat! I felt so cheated when my plate came out, dumplingless.

4gn0ouyN9CwzuYoiGLXMPQ.review_text: This place is great and is surprisingly big to accommodate larger parties. I'm not a fan of the all you can eat and drink.... why? Well, unlike most people I like to get drunk, esp. since you order all you can drink... right? I mean why else would someone order all you can drink..... to get ripped... anyhoo, I ate to much and as a result, the food outweighed the drinks = \ This shouldn't take away from the great food and atmosphere you can only get from a Shabu restaurant. The kobe beef is a must, along with the spicy ponzu! Plus you can't help but love the old Japanese man that always smiles and slices your meat for you! The staff is friendly and when coming from out-of-town, they are pretty handy with directions (as I'm not). I would say this is a good place to start if you are new to the Shabu scene.

Edl8CH1HduzkJwEV4rhOPA.review_text: This would be a five star review if not for the busted burner I got stuck with.  Otherwise, $35 all you can eat and drink WINS.

oKiEiIp4bcfMBOAoGMFJrA.review_text: Come here to be stuffed with pretty good shabu meat! You get your own pot of miso soup and generous portions of both veggies and meat. I got an order of beef and the meat plate was huge comparatively. And the beef was REALLY nice compared to some places which have really thick meat or meat with a grainy texture. An order of beef also came with good amounts of cabbage, bok choy, mushrooms,tofu, and two types of noodles. There are also three types of dipping sauces but I usually don't use any  sauce.  If you are still hungry, you can easily upgrade to ALL YOU CAN EAT for $22.95, just $6 more, and ask for more of whatever you need. Some all you can eat places get stingy and give small refills but not here! We had to ask for smaller refillls since we were getting stuffed! Great service. The owner was our waiter and super polite and attentive.   I love the shabu shabu in Korea and have been looking for a place in SF that has Korean style shabu shabu. Most places have been more Japanese style which is okay but just not as satisfying. This place has good meat but the soup and sauces were just okay.  This place is still pretty good and we will keep coming back! (Out of the like 6 shabu places we've tried, the only other place we go back to is G Cube.)

kUeMRDlXAnqAugNzGLxV-w.review_text: I discovered this place last week and have already eaten there twice.  Good healthy food at a great price. $5 for a large beer.  What else can you ask for.

dg6ueU_YY07oLog-z0AOUA.review_text: A San Francisco favorite on cold, foggy summer nights.

hvjhcPOG8zuqqLOohDKBmA.review_text: My boyfriend and I walked in and the whole place supposedly had reservations, so we ended up sitting at the bar counter where each seat has its own outdated coil electric stove top.    When we came in, we overheard one of the waiters talking to the owner that was sitting nearby rating my looks on how I have a cat face in Cantonese as that is my boyfriend and I's native language. I was more shocked that this establishment came to be the type to talk crap about their customers rather than what they said about my looks alone.     My boyfriend and I did the all you can eat which consist of beef, chicken, and vegetables for roughly 23 dollars a person. The vegetables consist of napa, baby bok-choy, a carrot, a chive, some mein/vermicelli, three small cube tofu, and enoki mushrooms.    The quality of our meat was poor, I was sick of it by the end of the night. The sauce they offered for dipping was delicious. It came in a peanut sauce, beef satay sauce, and vinegar-soy sauce. There is only one soup base which was a basic chicken broth.   An old employee was slicing our beef on the machine in front of us and was very helpful although he did not speak English.Our crap-talking waiter on the other hand offered crappy service and was hanging out in the kitchen most of the time and seemed annoyed whenever we asked him for more tea, more vegetables, or to simply raise or lower our heat.  When we spoke Cantonese to him, he had the huh expression on his face as he realized that he was BUSTED!    OVERALL EXPERIENCE: Super low-quality meat, bad service that talks crap, nice ambiance, soup base might as well have been the original shabu shabu, water.    I have been to a number of shabu shabu's and this would be the worst one of all.

vD65y5E3Az3bFc6UW4G1eA.review_text: I kinda love this place.  As I am new to the whole world of shabu shabu, my SF network is convinced this was the best of the best when it came to all you can drink and eat that was closest to our neck of the woods.  We were here on two separate occasions, so this will be a merging of those reviews.  The large group dinner: We had a huge group of 20 or so.  Most of us did all you can drink and eat.  When its a large group, the table/burners are placed a bit far so it is hard to talk to the people across the way.  If doing the all you can drink, drinks are plentiful.  The owner comes around with this horrible, and possible illegal beverage he pours shots of.  Quite terrible, and definitely don't drink it.  It wasn't crowded for a Friday night, and it runs about $38 per person.  Not bad for a night of good food and drinking.   The small girls dinner:  About 6 of us.  So we were able to just be at two bar areas.  Again.. the gap in the center of the tables does make it a challenge to hear each other, and less intimate but we made it work.  No drinking this time around, but good food and company made it an enjoyable experience  The food:  The broth is a miso based broth, which was tasty.  They have three dipping sauces to suit your palate.  There is a variety of vegetables which is nice with two kinds of mushrooms.  The meat was sliced thin and tasty and the chicken was ok.  I preferred the beef over the chicken, but that is just my own personal choice.  They also offer up two kinda of noodles to throw in the pot, which my girlfriend was all about.    The service:  The owner was entertaining and definitely wanted to make it a rowdy place.  But all in all, the servers were attentive and offering often if we wanted more protein and vegetables.  They also responded well to our specific demands on the type of veggies we wanted instead of bringing the variety plate.  All in all.  This is a good place for a crowd.  You know going into it how much each person will spend, and you can literally simmer here for a couple hours eating slowly since the food is cooking and drinking.  But watch out. Those sake bombs creep up on you :)

edOcRaWzbMvCKztQQJe_4A.review_text: Nice cozy place. Serivce is good. I would recommend beef hotpot, it is better compare to chicken hotpot. However it's not the best in town.

0ajweLSi0Zz8tYQGAVdJiA.review_text: I'm obliged to follow suit of the Happy Yelping Yelpers below and give my props to STEVE. Go to this place. Eat, drink & be merry with this jovial human being. He will provide you with entertainment & libations up the wazzzz. Talk about Customer Service!

CIyICwrEeEVCuuBUmaSdOQ.review_text: All You Can Eat $22.95 Beef, Chicken and Vegetables(for entire party only)  All You Can Eat & Drink $34.95 Beef, Chicken and Vegetables Beer , House Sake and Soda

IXpspuR_OCbgyYV06lnMqg.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu might just be my all time favorite place to eat in my neighborhood (and maybe in San Francisco).  I live right above, and my boyfriend and I have been known to frequent there more than once a week at times.  I've tried other shabu shabu places in the city, but this is by far the best.  Everything (and I mean everything) is incredibly fresh, the staff is attentive and friendly and the place has a fun atmosphere.  Unlike other places I have been, there's no other choice of what to eat besides shabu shabu (beef, chicken, or seafood I think... although I have only tried the beef), which makes ordering easy and quick, especially if you are hungry.  The all you can eat special is also awesome and a great deal, my boyfriend and I ploughed through a pitcher of beer, two sakes, and about 3 plates of meat each... well worth it.  Usually we just go for one order each and some hot sake and it's more than enough food.    The other thing I think is awesome is their three sauces to dip your meat in: ponzu, spicy, and sesame.  So good.  I would go here every day if I could.

tf6qwu65_2byTdSewOFBIg.review_text: So I came here with a friend last week, we got there about 9pm. So we sit down and look at the menu and as we are looking the waitress says "you know we close at 10, is that gonna be enough time for you?" Kinda rude to already be telling us 'you have exactly one hour to eat and leave' so we said yeah no problem. Problem here is she proceeded to say this every time she came back to check on us, RUDE. After deciding what we wanted to eat my friend orders the all you can eat and drink and I TRIED to order just the one portioned beef selection....our waitress straight up told me I had to order the all you can eat and drink if my friend ordered it. Obviously this place is worried about you sharing even a bite of there food. Im sorry but that is RIDICULOUS. How are you just gonna tell a CUSTOMER they have to order something. We were just there for a quick bite so understandably I wasn't trying to spend close to $40 on food. Aside from the rude service the food was excellent. Definitely go for the food and do your best to ignore the pushy waitresses.

fU7WxVPi3Or_Y2pkxfttLA.review_text: On my way to a flick at the JCL, stopped here on Fillmore across from Yoshi's and 1300, both gourmet boîtes which this is not.  I was looking for something homey. Last time I did shabu-shabu was in New York some 30 years ago. Loved it then, or maybe just delighted by the novelty. The fish and seafood here was freezer-burned and stiff before dipping in bland miso broth. Sauces included a sesame dressing (not bad on the noodles, but nothing to write home about,) plain soy sauce, and a hotter soy heavy on the Tabasco, with sesame seed floaters. There were jars of diced scallion and celery, and minced garlic - which the broth badly needed.  Soba and bean thread noodles, one slice of carrot, one shiitake mushroom, one scallion spear, some bok choy and Chinese cabbage, and several cubes of tofu rounded out the dish. These items were to be placed in a dish smaller than the sauce bowls. Ginger would have lent a bit of flavor. As it was, the best- tasting part of the meal was the rice green tea. The hip-hop music provided the "homies." I give it 3 stars because the waitress was very sweet and attentive.

QsMLT06-s4vltVIz8DgpMw.review_text: Our group of 6 went in on a Saturday night at 7:30. The place wasn't too crowded, so if you wanted to do a walk-in, I'm sure it wouldn't be a huge issue.   We elected to go with the AYCE and AYCD option. The quality of the beef was excellent. It didn't change regardless of how many servings we had. Pork and chicken seemed to be of great quality too; although I'm not really a fan of chicken at shabu in general.   What else can I say? The broth was delicious, and the vegetables were fresh.   FYI, if you get the all you can drink option, there is a 2-hour time limit.   Would definitely go again!

PKPt-PE4BMQ0ZHuGnXulAQ.review_text: Came here the other night for a friends birthday. The broth was tasteless. All the sauces were watered down. The owner was pretty annoying.

uTSGqJGFwngSLTSckILesw.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu was my second shabu experience and definitely awesome!! They have a lot of choices on the menu including seafood, so you aren't just stuck with beef, beef and more beef. All you can eat and drink is $35.   All of the chairs have a pot for your shabu, so you aren't sharing one pot for 4 or 5 people which I think is awesome!!   The staff is super friendly and all of the veggies are very fresh. There are a lot of bells and whistles on the table so you can spice up your shabu however you like.   It's a great spot that I'm sure I'll visit many more times.

w77iTT57YxYiadvBXIFe5A.review_text: My theory:  Whoever doesn't like shabu shabu is clearly someone that does not know how to enjoy food.    the food was awesome!  We had a huuge group but the owners were totally accomodating.  There's an option here where you can have all you can eat food and all you can drink liquor.  hee hee hee...you know the rest.  Well, I didn't pick that option, but with a menu choice like that I bet you can ensure a fun night of food and fun with your gang.

6ukaJ8F5c0hMvEgD8us8Uw.review_text: Came here last Saturday. This place gets 3.5 stars for the food and 1.5 stars for the owner being freaking awesome and the experience we had. My friends and I did the all you can eat/drink for $35/person. So worth it considering 2 of my friends passed out at the bar we went to after this place aka got our moneys worth!   Food: Okay pretty typical shabu shabu. The meats are thinly cut and seem pretty high quality. The beef and lamb were solid. Chicken is meh. I don't normally do chicken at shabu shabu places but someone in our group decided to get it. They also bring out 3 dipping sauces: ginger, spicy, and mustard. The mustard sauce was a little suspect, because I expected it to taste like the mustard dipping sauce from Benihana's. The broth was delicious after the lamb hit the hot water. The waitresses and owner are super accommodating and you will definitely get full from this place.   Experience: We had a group of 7 and they didn't have suitable seating for us to sit together inside so they set up the benches outside and cranked on the heat lamps. It was perfect for a summer night in SF (hence the heat lamps because it's never THAT NICE in SF). My friends and I were loud and obnoxious and outside seating was perfect. There's not a whole lot around there so we didn't bother anyone and no one bothered us. The owner drank shots with us and even poured us "special" drinks - the holy water and the hell? (eh forgot the name of the second shot, hence all you can drink) Holy water was essentially flavored soju and the hell shot was 129 proof (can't really remember...) of nasty rubbing alcohol.   To sum up the night, it was a shit show and we only paid $45 ($35 + generous tip) to be completely filled to the rim with delicious shabu shabu and more sake + beer than we could have ever needed or wanted. Good times, will definitely be back here with friends again.

uetYbt4WiCGrZWvH36zYlQ.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu is the place to go for shabu-lovers! Don't know what shabu is? It's sort of like Chinese hotpots but instead of sharing a hotpot to cook your food, each diner gets their individual pot.   I was brought in here on a business meeting and it has now turned into a weekly stop for me to fill that shabu craving! You start off with a plate of sliced beef and a plate of veggies, the pot gets heated up once your seated and is filled with ginseng and various little bubs for taste. Rice and extra noodle plates are on the house while beef is an extra charge for your 2nd plate and thereafter.  Definitely a must-go!

T4GxXDhoXVgh5OCoR9Nebg.review_text: Two of my friends and I showed up on Friday night without reservations, and we were able to get seats at the counter. When asked if we could sit at a table in the main dining area, we were told all tables were reserved. However, the main dining room was never full, even when we left at 10pm...  But on to the important part... The FOOD. My friends and I all got beef and chicken plates ($14.99/plate), and I ordered an extra plate of fishballs on the side ($8 for 6 balls). There was a decent amount of meat, although the veggies and noodles that came  as sides were smaller portioned than I expected (i.e. ONE shitake mushroom, two bites of noodles). The broth was ok-- basically diluted miso soup. The three dipping sauces were also lackluster, so I opted to eat everything "natural", aka without sauce.   Service was friendly, but not overly aggressive. When I sat down, the waitress immediately brought me a much needed cup of hot tea.   Overall, nothing particularly special about this place. Not terrible, not amazing, and you could do a lot better if you headed a few miles outside Japantown to the Richmond.

ACUVZ4SiN0gni7dzVDm9EQ.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu is a pretty basic/traditional shabu place. They've got standard offerings of beef, chicken, veggie, or seafood with no frills. However, they do give everyone your own pot for cooking which is nice. And the broth they use is pretty tasty, too. Considering that, and that it's right around the corner from my house I will likely be back.  The other nice thing is that you can get noodles and vegetable accompaniments or just all of one. And they have an all you can eat special for just over $20. I personally can't eat more than the regular serving size they give you in just one order, but if you having a particularly hungry day this is a nice option.

qR33aCiEU2hbq5fBC-dFOw.review_text: This place was pretty cheap for the all-you-can eat option.  It was also pretty damn tastey.  There were some problems though.  Let me put it in context:  It was a stormy, rainy night, and we had a party of 12.  To suit our size, they put us outside.  This was fine, but the heating units appear to have been on a timer.  They turned themselves off every 20-30 minutes, at which point we'd have to request that they turn it back on.  With that said, the manager seemed to be the biggest penny pincher I have ever seen.  He wouldn't let us have more than 4 grills for 12 ppl, even though one of us was a vegetarian, and one of us was eating seafood.  His reason?  He didn't want to waste the propane.    When it came to the all-you-can-eat AND drink option,  the restaurant has some stupid rule that if any one person is doing all you can drink, everyone has to do all your can drink.  To re-phrase, you can't have some doing all you can drink, and others doing a-la-carte.  He was afraid that we would be sharing drinks, I guess, but come on.  We're adults.  Likewise, the all-you-can-eat people have to have a separate burner from those not doing all-you-can-eat.  Oh, and apparently sodas were not part of the-all-you-can-drink deal.  I suggest that if the manager is reading, he consider investing in a fountain soda machine.  When it came time to leave, we respectfully requested that we be allowed to split the bill several ways.  To answer our request, the manager sent out a calculator, a pen and paper, and told us to divey it up, but only 6 ways max.  If you're already allowing us to split 6 ways, why not 12 ways?  Dumb.  The one bright spot of this night was Serena, our server.  She was awesome, hands down!  Many thanks to her for putting up with us.

kp1SDNjwwBPFmdF1kadRmw.review_text: Not bad, but I prefer Nabe in the Inner Sunset. The broth is kind of bland, but you get plenty of veggies and meat, for $15 (if you get the beef shabu). They're pretty prompt with service and come fill up your tea often. They give you 3 sauces to dip your food in. My favorite is the spicy sauce. The ponzu is pretty good too.

ZJcLjHFCfkMbbDwBB2Q70Q.review_text: More like 2.5 stars really. I don't have any big complaints about this place. The service, prices, and environment were decent.  The food was just ... eh.  It would have been 3-4 stars if the food had pushed my buttons a bit more.  The broth was very plain and it felt like I was basically cooking in plain boiling water.  Sure there are sauces there but I'm a fan of shabu places that I can get some extra kick or flavor by just cooking in the pot.  I had to dump about half of the garlic and green onion self serve containers PLUS about a half plate of beef  just to get a little flavor in there.  I also ended up dumping some ponzu and hot sauce directly into the soup for the same reason.  The meat was a bit fatty at times ( I had about 4 plates worth ) and the chicken was as bland as can be since they were basically 1/4 inch slices of unmarinated chicken breast.   The veggie, noodle, tofu and mushroom selection was fine. But again, I wish the broth just had more kick to it as eating loads and loads of ponzu sauce flavored food gets old.  And this is from a huge ponzu fan.  It is VERY nice to get your own pot though. And the place itself was very clean and well organized.  So that's a definite plus.  Overall, decent but has plenty of room to improve for sure.  Maybe I'll come back if I hear of some changes later on.

iI5hC_uNUBGkkvtWrBIaZQ.review_text: Steve! Thanks for the holy water, fire water, and funky water!  How can you have a better shabu shabu experience than a place with a pot for each person?!?!?

5d-LvAXw5HDA8-eE6MhPRw.review_text: I went here tonight with a fried thinking it was a sushi place (why? i have no idea)  We walked in, and it became clear that I was mistaken, but how do you leave a place when you are the only ones there? So, we sat down and tried to figure out from the menu what we had gotten ourselves in.  We ordered (vegetarian for me, chicken for her). I was amazed when the big plate of veggies came out! She showed us what to do, and in just a few min we had yummy boiled vegetables with delicious sauces... What more could you ask for?  I can't wait to go back!

_pIG1_s6Bzymn1zeyLjBHQ.review_text: Have you ever cheated on your lover?  I haven't.  But now I have a good idea of what it might feel like.  Last night, after placing a call to Shabu House at 9:30, the waitress informed me that their kitchen closes at 9:30, it's too late to come.  Alright - but what to do now?  I had a massive craving for Shabu House.  Then the idea occurred to me.  Desperate times call for desperate measures  -- I'd have to try another.  Enter:  Happy Shabu Shabu. Now, I have heard of this place, and I had read some of the reviews some time ago - and while my brain found it impossible to process the possibility that anything on the planet might be better than Shabu House, a closed kitchen doesn't help me at all, so off to Happy Shabu we headed.  Now, there is no doubt that Rob and I can eat.  We were hungry, and ready to battle the beef, so to speak.  I felt guilty, though I really shouldn't - but that wasn't going to stop me from eating.  Here is what we noted:  1.  Seating is really strange.  I read that it was strange, and indeed, it was strange. 2.  Service is very friendly - - young servers, and all helpful, but service, compared to Shabu House, was slower.   It took a significant amount of time to even begin the meal.  That said, each additional plate of meat came at the speed of light. 3.  Soup:  they, like my SH, have a "miso-soup" but there was NO comparison.  NONE.  We spent the majority of our time "fixing" the soup with what condiments they had - - but never really succeeded. 4.  Sauces:  Ponzu sauce was OK, sesame sauce was lesser, but they served a spicy sauce - which was quite good.  However, they do not have the radishes.... ponzu w/ no radish??? 5.  All-you-can-eat option is FIRST - CHEAPER... by some 7 dollars per person, and second - consists of beef and chicken, instead of beef and lamb.  The chicken was a nice addition but by half a plate, I didn't want anymore - and stuck to beef only. 6.  Speaking of beef - -  it's not American Kobe like Shabu House - and you can tell.  It really wasn't bad, and much better than Shabu-Sen's regular beef, but it wasn't comparable to that of Shabu House.   7.  Veggies:  no spinach, tons of Napa Cabbage, two kinds of noodles (glass and fresh) and mushrooms, etc.  I love spinach, ding.  The noodles were a good addition compared to Shabu House's udon noodles, but I am not there for the noodles. 8.  They are opened later.  This is always a plus!  For $7 less per person, all of the above makes it a reasonable place to go to dinner when craving Shabu. But - and this is a BIG BUT - their atmosphere completely ruined it for me.  Twenty plus year old, rather vulgar and so extremely LOUD people stood around, pushing each other, swearing, and general creating chaos in the middle of the restaurant, in their drunken stupor.  I am all for having fun, but to ruin other diners' experience to this extent was inexcusable.  They seemed to know the staff there, and while I understand some exceptions - - if you want your other patrons to come, you have to get a grip on your customers.  I understand the appeal of this place to the younger crowd.  It's cheaper and you can get just as full.  But due to it being a younger crowd - their selection of higher-end sake was non-existent, and most opted for the all you can drink w/ hot sake or beer pitchers.    If you like beer or hot sake, and you don't mind a ton of havoc around you while eating, then Happy Shabu might be more up your alley compared to Shabu House, for considerably less amount of money.  If having some sense of calmness around you while eating matters at all to you -  you can trust me on this:  you won't like it here.  All in all, I would not be inclined to return to this place except if absolutely necessary.  I would have given this place a 3.5, but am taking it down to a 2.5 (rounded up to 3) due to the atmosphere in this place.  See? Cheating is NEVER worthwhile!

jzODNU5ZSdBf2sil4G5eAw.review_text: Not a fan of this place at all. Having eaten at shabuway, mum's etc, I was truly disappointed in the quality of meat at this location. In addition, for some reason their pots, even when turned to the highest, is very slow to cook. They were not very fast with service as well, hesitating and taking their time when we asked for more plates of meat. Their veggie plate was mostly cabbage and really not much of anything else.   The staff also stands around either looking annoyed or chatting with each other loudly in canto.   Will not be back.

bCdZCR3VmGz5fqiQpLiI2g.review_text: Note - this review is about the refusal to honor the "free birthday meal" and the company's refusal to correct its billing.  This restaurant advertises a "Birthday Free Beef or Chicken Shabu - Party of 6 and more (Must present ID)" per the company website. My girlfriend held her birthday party at this establishment last night (2/24/11) with a party of 7 and had mentioned when making the reservation that this was for her birthday. At the end of the night when we received the bill, the restaurant had not honored the free meal as advertised both on the website and menu. When we asked them to honor the free meal, the individual in charge of the restaurant told us that they could not reprint the bill and that we would have to pay for the meal. We argued about this for 5-10 minutes with the restaurant representative raising his voice, being short and holding the restaurant's position that a bill cannot be reprinted and that we would therefore have to pay the inaccurate amount on the bill. I guess as not to make a scene, we relented and paid the inaccurate amount.  The restaurant attempted to offer consolation by saying we could get the free meal the next time around and proceeded to hand us a 10% off coupon valid for the next 30 days. Clearly not the same as the $14.95 value of a meal. Obviously, there is no reason to even believe they'd honor a coupon if they don't honor their menu advertisement.  On a side note, the waitress who works at this establishment is really nice - but she is literally asked to do 99% of the work here. The guy who talked down to us and refused to honor the deal literally watched soap operas on his laptop at the bar the entire duration of our stay, while the other guy who slices the meat does only that (this must occupy 5 minutes every hour on average). Meanwhile, the overall service is strained (it's hard to order drinks, get water/tea, etc.) while 2 of the 3 people in sight are standing around refusing eye contact or assistance.   There are other shabu shabu establishments that are just as good if not better in terms of food. You don't need to waste your time/effort here.

tBj0MAEYrFnl1Lvas-mfrg.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu didn't make me very happy. I'm going to list everything that made me displeased with this inappropriately named restaurant.  1) Service was awful - we asked for rice and water at least 3 times, while waiting for more than 10 minutes to finally get them. 2) They were unaccommodating - a few of us wanted to get the all you can eat, but if even one person gets all you can eat, everyone in our party has to, also. After finding this out, we tried to split our party up, but they still wouldn't let us. Rude. 3) The food was OK. I've had way better at other Shabu restaurants in the city.   4) They tried kicking us out as we were getting the bill.   Simply put, don't go here. Parking is impossible to find anyway.

BnEjkNIqA1SocRx9AgKbWA.review_text: I would definitely come back here.  The service was great and the food was delicious.  I really liked having my own pot.  I ordered the all you can eat menu and had 4 plates of beef!  I also loved the sesame sauce to dip the meats in.

38HgIu6SObZ_q4XyCY5qDQ.review_text: I only come here for the all you can eat/all you can drink special... usually for a birthday or some other random occasion. It is hands down, a fabulous time. All you can eat plates of meat and veggies, and all you can drink sake and beer. What?? There is no way this can ever go wrong. We always get reservations a week or so ahead of time, and have never had a problem getting seated right away. We usually leave really really intoxicated and full and happy.   Secret tip - if you're with a huge group and you're all doing all you can eat, get everyone in your party to bring cash (and include a big tip) and collect it before you start eating. After two hours of all you can drink sake and beer, trying to do that crap sucks. Take it from a Happy Shabu Shabu pro.

HAv257_IVJnQT0ZIL8Nn-Q.review_text: So i went here the other night with some friends. It is different than the other places I have have been too. We got our own personal pots, but instead of a bar for each of us to sit at, it sort of felt like a desk. We were isolated from each other two. 4 Pots, in 2x2 formation. The place was cool though. They gave you plane miso and let you spice it with whatever you wanted. They have an awesome spicy sauce that is not overpowering and very tangy. The meet selection included beef and chicken. For all you can eat, I recommend going all beef. Chicken just seems too risky for such things. And besides boiled chicken is meh. The place was pretty good with service too. But because of the setup of the place it seemed sort of clunky at times. For instance my friend had to wait about 10 minutes before a plate refill since he was stuck behind a rather large group sort of blocking us in.  Overall not a bad place but since I had just found Shabuhouse it wouldn't be fair to rank this place the same as them. Also btw, don't even think about parking at the Safeway across the street. The sign says 1.5 hours, and it really mean 1 hour. We had to go to the towing yard right after dinner.

7GYVakMOomhL7C9l5XaUtA.review_text: This place is great! Excellent service (loved our waitress Serena was so attentive and sweet), delicious food. I always get the all you and eat and drink, its so worth it! I mean come on a shot at the club is the same price as their all you can drink sake which comes hot OR cold. The meat is super fresh and I love geting seafood because the fishballs they serve are sooo good. I also like the seating set up, especially outside because not only do they have heat lamps, it'll keep you from smelling like food the rest of the night.  Also, all the celebrities come here for some reason, you get to see them if you come here often enough.

zPVd90RyrqI4Oew3673amw.review_text: Don't go here for the food, but if you want to get your drink on then give it a try.

m6MQjiC2b7vaQkwCxpAKYg.review_text: All you can eat and drink is a good deal, but they should offer more of a selection of meats.

EQ-fPVMNGhwZOdB8PJ25ug.review_text: returned to this place a few weeks later with friends.   the staff (there weren't many) couldn't be RUDER and less accommodating to customers. never experienced anything like that and will NEVER go back. ... terrible

S34qI4Jvdn-Nn5rfuKzgYw.review_text: Continuing on with the theme of over consumption, we arrived at Happy Shabu Shabu for the ALL YOU CAN EAT AND DRINK fiesta.   The place is clean, the food is fresh, and really, all you can eat and drink for 2 hours (meaning that you must finish ordering in 2 hours but can sit and eat for as long as you like). Our waitress was as cheerful and feisty as anyone would like to see at an ALL YOU CAN EAT/DRINK restaurant--- she'll call you a wuss for not finishing your pitcher of beer (some people need that kind of encouragement, you know).   The scary truth: I was able to finish 2 and 2/3 plates of beef, 1 plate of veggies and tofu, 2 small bottles of cold sake, and 1 glass of beer.   The scarier truth: I thought about going back the next night.

XDQCUG6dB_NntrZNsn5Frw.review_text: "Meh" just about sums this place up for me.  Pros: Fresh ingredients, good quality meat, prompt service (this could be bad, a bit overbearing . . . I felt like I was being watched all the time), kind staff who warned us that our car would get towed away if we parked in the Safeway parking lot. We were very grateful for this. We moved our car to avoid having it towed.  Cons:  1) Table set-up: This place is not good for a group. Everyone has to be seated on a row as if you're sitting at a bar and you can't really face each other. Four of us were facing the same wall, talking loudly in a desperate attempt to have a conversation.   2) Individual Shabu Shabu pot: This defeats the purpose of Shabu Shabu. It's supposed to be communal meal, shared with friends and family. The sharing aspect is totally ignored.  3) Miso broth: I expect Shabu Shabu to be prepared with dashi (usually seaweed based) broth. That's the traditional way. Miso broth is a little strange . This was a dead giveaway that the owner of this place is most likely not Japanese. It tasted fine, and actually some of my dining companions thought it was very flavorful. I didn't care for it.  This place was disappointing. I will not be back!

ibvH1Y7Rh_tstiWgH0OFTA.review_text: Their sauces are good, and their broth base is really good, too! I just wish they gave more mushrooms in the veggie dish but all in all, this place is clean, nice layout, and delicious!  Can't wait to come back...

TmfYoFVydVLLtGeY7yHMig.review_text: I like this place.  The price is decent. The food is good. And the service is great. We had Serena as our server. I heard she is not working there anymore. =( She was very attentive, fun and easy going.   I will come back to this place.   PS. If they can add like ramen noodles and eggs into the menu, that would be awesome.
