Rm53TvM9sAHrsHVP3d5TtA.review_text: If I could give this place negative stars, I would.  The Shabu is ok, and conveniently located so I have been going frequently over the last 3 years with a good friend of mine that also lives in the neighborhood.  HOWEVER I will not be giving them a penny of my money ever again.  The owner of this restaurant is one of the rudest men I have ever met in my entire life.  I am a vegetarian so I always get just the veggie platter while she (a meat LOVER of epic proportions) always gets the AYCE [all you can eat] of meat.  They have never given us any problems, never said a word to us, until we went in the the day before yesterday and the incredibly rude owner talked to us like we were some lowly asians not worthy of eating at his "fine" establishment.  He told us if one person got ACYE, everyone in the party has to get AYCE with no exceptions and that it has been his policy for the last at least 2 years.  When we told him how frequently we come and how we were never made aware of that rule before, he wouldn't believe us and aggressively asked for names of his staff who had done it so he could deal with them (we obv. didn't say anything, so, no worries!).  He was incredibly condescending when he told us that both of us had to get AYCE and that he couldn't care less that I was vegetarian or that fact I could barely finish the vegetarian platter let alone do justice to an AYCE because he is there for the money period and forcing AYCE is the way he does it.  Honestly, if he had been nice, hell if he had just been NOT an a-hole, I would have gotten the AYCE.  If you are vegetarian and don't want to pay ridiculous amounts of money for your dinner when you eat with your meat loving friends, there are plenty of other GREAT shabu places in the city with management who are kind and good hearted that I can recommend to you.  Just send me a message! :)

ee7CYx19I9JaluVgkGAGGA.review_text: This is the kind of thing my dad hates -- "What? I have to make my own stew? I could do this better at home!"  What makes this place great is the excellent kobe beef , wonderfully fresh and tasty vegetables, and how goddam fantastically clean it is. SO CLEAN! The staff are great, all very friendly japanese girls who are quick to fill up your tea, and clean out your beef sludge.  We consider this place for "special occasions" because of how pricey it is, but damn it's worth it every time. (Delicious ice cream/watermelon tapioca dessert, TASTY!)

5pBi1CSpm9467jh7PSBDkA.review_text: This was my first experience with the Korean style shabu-shabu.  However I've done the Japanese (traditional style) several times before.  I do enjoy the nice changes they've made.  The different sauces are awesome and the one she'll mix for you (with lots of garlic!) is amazing.  It's a nice change to the subtle tastes of the oldschool way.  Yes having your own pot is nice and I did like it because when you do tranditional shabu-shabu someone eventually becomes the cook for everyone else.    HOWEVER!!  I do like the closeness you get from sharing pots.  I missed it a little at this location.  Everything is so segregated, it was my friends birthday and there was about 10 of us and we were all so separated.  Had to yell to talk to some of the girls across the tables from us.  I like the group pot in old shabu-shabu because it creates a familyish mealtime vibe which this experience lacks.  The food was awesome, the waitresses very helpful and fast, everything was fresh and clean.  Great experience overall.  Note: It's BYOB.

Rhwi_JFSjwek9zJMsXq86Q.review_text: The only two things you ask for from a restaurant like this are the fresh beef and good dipping sauce. They got both. With a selection of 3 dipping sauces, they really can't go wrong.   One star was for the friendly service. Nice.

RmxvvwZpjTwO0fvDj9ak3Q.review_text: I have been here a few times and have had different experiences each time.  This last time compelled me to write a review.   SERVICE: We showed up at 6:30 and the restaurant was pretty empty.  We asked for a table for two (no reservations) and she said we can sit at the counter.  I asked if we could sit a table and she said, "No, they are taken."  However, when another couple came in not too long after us with no reservations, they were seated AT A TABLE!  Hmmm.  When I looked at who the waitress was choosing to sit at a table vs. the counter, I felt she was deciding based on race.    Service was also based on race as the guys next to us were getting waited on hand and foot and we had to keep asking for more of this and that.  I have never experienced this before and was quite disappointed this time.  Service is a hit or miss depending on the day and the waitress.    The best part was when three people came in and stated, "We have reservations for three at 7:00."  The waitress had the nerve to look at me and my boyfriend who were sitting at the counter to see if we were almost done and she did it rudely too.  The things you notice while sitting at the bar.   FOOD: I always order the all you can eat.  This time I ordered all you can eat with just chicken and my boyfriend ordered chicken and beef.  However, she made us share a chicken plate and kept bringing us more.  I think there should be a price difference if you are only eating one kind of protein vs. two.  But that silly rule of "if one person is getting all you an eat, everyone has to."  They have this fear of food sharing! Oh my!  I like the three different sauces they give you and the vegetable platter is plentiful but they over do it on the cabbage.  TV:  I never really paid attention but they had the TV on a gruesome, bloody zombie movie.  Not good for those who have a weak stomach.

Mh3nZA2Rpn8TfFyoVxn9Vg.review_text: The all you can eat is so so nice! Only problem was they had to roll me out. Great meat and service. loved the spicy dipping sauce. I did not like that tables are separated if you are more than 2 people.

2TN-jjYg98_cPNft8OJHCw.review_text: I give them 4 stars alone for the All you can eat and drink choice for $35. Not bad - however, I'm not a big fan of shabu shabu.  We were invited here for my cousin-in-law's birthday so I didn't do the choosing but thought it was a fun place to celebrate an event.  There was about 20 of us and we had tons of fun.   By the end of the night, the birthday girl was feeling the after effects of the sake and beer she enjoyed from the "all you can drink choice.    I may have to take my brother's here next time we're celebrating or just for fun!

ZGT9H35Edi4y8rHYSqSKfg.review_text: Affordable Shabu spot in the Jtown. Definitely good for big parties and if you're looking to get you drink on.  Entertaining owner, as well. Always getting in the middle of the parties like he was part of the group. Love it. Bring on the rubbing alcohol! Ha, if you're here often, you'll know what I'm talking about.  Broth and meat quality is not up to par with some of the others but it is less crowded, more roomy, and the freedom to get rowdier than the other spots.  Party Shabu.

KI7gPbRvdngGcgq3-RD7Gw.review_text: Happy fooding, unhappy service!!  We were meeting my friend's new beau so hoping to get to know him over a few (or many) sake bombs -- but the seating arrangement made it impossible.  Not sure why anyone would consider building it that way, but our table of six basically had 3 of us facing the other 3 -- but about 10 feet apart!  The silver lining is that we had 4 pots between the 6 of us so non-spicy eaters had no problem.  Food was decent -- the AYCE ($23, with AYCD $35) provided ample quality beef, mushrooms, cabbage, tofu, and two types of noodles.  Happy Shabu is a few bucks cheaper than Mum's, which is great -- and the quality of food does not suffer as a result...but it's really the only reason it still has 3 stars...  The service is DEPLORABLE.  Our server was not mean -- but he was one of the slowest and dullest people I've met to date.  I pitied the guy. He carried plates ONE at at time, and obviously had no sense of adaptation/flexibility.  Since 6 of us ordered AYCE, he went ahead and brought out 6 plates of beef, 6 plates of veggies, 18 sauces (even though there was no space on the table) but somehow gave us zero napkins.  We spent half the dinner trying to get more beer, sake, and food.  Not sure if his dragonball hair cut cut off his vision, but he always seemed to forget us.  After 2 hours -- they actually cut off our alcohol.  It make sense and is pretty fair, BUT I'd clearly state it on the menu if such was the policy.   Sadly, I'll probably come back again as shabu is one of our favorite night out activities and options are limited here in SF --- but happy shabu, you got some work to do...

OJ8vx4pJFSZ34orEOo-txA.review_text: I have to say I am a fan of hot pot restaurants. Some people think it is lame that you cook your own food, but if you don't suck, you think it is fun.  I got the beef (there are not really very many options on the menu) and was very happy.  The meat was excellent, the veggies were so-so, and the sake was plentiful.  When we got there, there was like 1 person in the entire place, and the host asked if we had reservations (we didn't) and we thought he was joking, but by the time we were finished, the entire place was full!  I would recommended making a reservation if you go late, or like us, show up early if you want to guarantee a seat.

M3F4a8F-FYmwZbHPUSvt4A.review_text: This place ain't bad...the meat was fresh, good assortment of veggies, & attentive service. only con: the weird setup of tables. We had a group of 6 ppl and we all sat in one table side by side sorta thing (like a picnic table) so it was really hard to talk amongst each other. I think the next time we go, we gotta bring like 12 ppl ..that way, we take up the entire 2 tables of 6 & we can all chat w/each other.  loved the all u can eat & drink but be aware...it's something like if 2 ppl at ur table decide on all u can eat & DRINK--then EVERYONE at the table must order that. given that some ppl at my table dont drink...i was the only one to order the all u can eat & drink (everyone else just did the regular all u can eat) & i shared my sake & beer pitcher w/the other folks at table (just do it w/o waitresses seeing--duh!)

NUKJzFCVulazp4YuGoqBOw.review_text: I love hot pot, but this isn't what I expected to be. I didn't like the food (meat) just got out of the freezer. I think I rather eat at a regular chinese hot pot. I gave it 3 stars for the atmosphere and most of all, my kids loved it! They enjoy to have their own cooking space. As long as they are happy, I'm happy!... but I will not return. :)

Valva2MGzBW8ux3641YINA.review_text: Funny, I'm not a huge Shabu Shabu fan but I managed ending up eating at 2 in 1 month. This place was ok, my only complaint they need a bell to get the waitress over faster so I can eat more. Food seemed fresh, and I dind't get sick from eating with the raw chicken chopsticks by accident, bonus points ha! gross!

YXRbcWEAULrYPTkJBOhbVw.review_text: Went her last night for the first time with a couple of friends. It's a bit hidden, so you have to know to look for it. We actually made reservations, but there was no need to. Place was kind of empty. The staff was really friendly and the decor was nice, clean, & modern. Different from past experiences I've had at other shabu shabu spots. We had the beef & seafood dishes between 3 people and that was plenty. Everything was tasty and easy to cook. There weren't a lot of options as for sides, like the other spots I've been too. It felt a bit Americanized, so perhaps they figure keep it simple for us dumb white Americans, lol. I'd definitely go back with a small group. It could be lots of fun. Unfortunately no desserts here, so either fill up, or plan on going somewhere else after if you have a sweet tooth.

32Y8ZSJ11chiJJuraiVB_Q.review_text: I'm not sure how reliable my review is, since I was pretty shmammered through my entire meal.  I didn't pay the bill, but apparently it's like $35/person for all you can eat AND all you can drink sake?  Came with a group of five... sat at a long table.  Wish we were sat at an actual table so that conversation would've been easier, but oh well.  The meat was good quality (it wasn't any premium kobe beef, but hey, it's all you can eat!), from what I remember, and they weren't stingy with the side dishes of noodles, veggies, etc.  Loved the spicy dipping sauce.  Sake kept flowing... meat kept coming as long as we asked...  Someone came out near the end of our meal with some kind of 130-proof Japanese or Korean whiskey.  I passed.  It smelled like pure gasoline, but that was very nice of him to offer that for free to our group.  Anyways, fun place for a group, and there's karaoke right across the street if you wish to continue your drinking shenanigans afterwards!

PJGD7zKksRjePnAIppFoiQ.review_text: Bland Bland Bland Bland broth. Everytime I've come here, I dump half of my ponzu and sesame sauce into the broth to get any kind of flavor. The meat is standard quality, nothing spectacular. Sometimes the owner is around, and he gives us free shots (yay!) , but sometimes he hangs around too long making dinner kind of awkward (boo).

9Axumg_V_EGsoVv369kvRQ.review_text: Um, did shots of fire water with the owner.  Don't remember much except I sang Heal the World at a karaoke bar afterwards.  So obviously I got rewarded by the All You Can Eat All You Can Drink arrangement.  Oh, and the beef (that you cook yourself) was delectable.

KmqivnDXe3mVjBtp9ZxkOQ.review_text: we went on friday night and there were only two people in there. we had gone on a different Friday and they were completely full. so we tried to make reservations but they said they only make reservations for groups of 3 or more.   was very impressed with this place. i liked that i got my own pot as my bf hates onions and i was able to have as many as my heart  desired. we got the all you can eat and drink. i liked that they gave us a pitcher of beer so we did not have to worry about asking for refills. they were also very timely with the sake too. i wasn't very impressed with the selection of veggies and noodles. i barely ate it. i think it would have been easier to eat if the bowls were a little larger to accommodate both meat and noodles/ veggies. the sauces that they had were pretty good. i even enjoyed the spicy sauce because it was not as spicey as i thought it was.

OCcHlcwqFtHcKFo5t4UBYA.review_text: Are people really complaining about this place having bland sauce, broth, and not liking the idea of having their own pot? Who cares. I am so glad this place is cheap where I can have unlimited meat and beer for the all low price of 22.95 (a little more if you do the sake and beer unlimited deal). The broth was hot, the waitress knew when to come over to refill my meat (I had three plates all to myself!). I tell you, it's better than any other shabu place I've been to. I'm also not picky. As long as someone just replenishes my all you can eat food, I'm fine. This place is amazing!

__05rytNjsye9MBhqB0DMA.review_text: In all fairness to the reviews, the place is really worth it, if you get the all you can eat and drink.  I went with a large group, 18 people, and the wait staff was very attentive to us. They kept on asking if we wanted a refill on the meats, veggies, and liquor.  I don't know if there is a time limit on the all you can eat, but they kept on refilling our plates, bottles, and pitchers.  We must have worked them overtime because the girls were all over the place.  And after awhile, so were we.   Taste wise the food was good, but after several plates and drinks of liquor everything tasted good. I can see why they call this place Happy Shabu Shabu, because everyone in my group left all Happy.  Full, Drunk and Happy.

3ureXPBb2cVbkNgM9oW5xA.review_text: Eh...   Happy Shabu Shabu did not make me happy.  Service wasn't bad, but definitely not great. Beef was alright.. veggies alright....  but......  they didn't have the grated daikon for dipping sauce!  Um... Grated daikon is a must with shabu sauce. Meh.   Also.....  rice was super hard.  Undercooked or they did not add enough water.  I mentioned it to the waitress and she did not do anything nor did any management come out to resolve the issue. Gross.  Come on, people... don't mess up the rice and SERVE it.  Making people pay for crappy rice does not make them happy.   Definitely somewhere I would never go back to next time I have a Shabu craving..

0qYv333UH9rEQmvEBlZiVg.review_text: The meat was delicious. However, the layout is hard for a party of four to have a conversation. The two people on the end basically just ate dinner. We had no problem with the all-you-can-eat being replenished often. The noodles were excellent, as well as the vegetables. The Napa cabbage was fresh and tasty. The meat ranged from very lean to moderately fatty.

L-U6TOUaLfrrhUHM2hGdDg.review_text: If you want good hot pot there are so many better places with much better service.   They just aren't very nice. The food was okay, if you want to eat here the best way to do it is the all you can eat and drink, just make sure everyone you're going with gets it or they'll be weird about it.   Otherwise I wouldn't recommend it.

GCRQ4ZfoDsBSmlJ8q85pCg.review_text: It's been awhile since I've been to Happy Shabu Shabu, well I went there tonight with some friends after work for their All You Can Eat Goodness.  It's pretty hard to mess up Shabu Shabu, it really depends on the service.  The service was great! We met Steve the Manager and it was a really cool guy.  He let us try his special spice mix the "Steve 22" and it really gave a good kick to the broth.  Also the waitress was very attentive and very nice.    It was the perfect end to a long day at work... The food and service alone get 4 stars, but the extra star goes to Steve and his staff.  Thanks!

qQa9J0fXA6E-3JSFNsF7TA.review_text: They are ok, I live closeby so it makes a good, closer alternative to my favorite spot in San Mateo.  IIRC, they don't use Kobe like the San Mateo spot but some other high grade beef.  I like Kobe just a little better.  Their portions are little smaller and cost more.  I'm a beef guy and they need to add an all beef plate to their menu.  The place is usually dead when I go there, and they're shady with the AC so it's always frigid.  Bring a jacket.  Also, last time I went they didn't have an alcohol license yet but you are welcome to hit up the Safeway across the street and bring your own Schlitz malt liquor.

08jfo0j-qbcs5yKefByVKQ.review_text: Although my Han-centric views have deemed shabu shabu as an off-putting translation of the Mongolian/Chinese hot pot, on a cold San Francisco evening even I will cave to the whims of boiled water and a single piece of kombu, awaiting plates of meat plus veggies.  Happy Shabu Shabu pretty much met my expectations of reasonable shabu shabu. It didn't convert me but it didn't disappoint, and was overall a nice experience. Quality of ingredients was pretty decent, everything looked pretty and of the appropriate shade of color. Not marbled meat, but good enough for a $15 one-person shabu shabu pot and plenty. Not enough? There's an abundance of mi-fun noodles and what I guess is supposed to be be udon. That would be my major complaint--the udon. Next to the large stick of carrot (really? bleh), my two least favorite ingredients on the list. Tofu and meat would be the top, but be warned--only two cubes of 1in. x 1in. tofu. Sad. I do want to come back to take advantage of their all-you-can-eat offering, including the all-you-can-drink sake and beer (uh, sake bombs plus pounds of beef? You're on!), about $40 I would guess with tax and tip. That sounds like quite the deal, and is cheaper than another shabu shabu place bookmarked on my list (Cafe Mum's), although Mum's is rated higher (have faith in your fellow Yelpers!)... Definitely time for a comparison. What made the experience memorable despite average food, average sauces and average service, was the combination of steam, two large bottles of Sapporo, cheering with friends who were just getting to know you and were afraid to know any more after realizing hot sake is your equivalent of Dr Hyde's little experiment, and knowing everyone passing by was freezing their tail off. Overall: not experienced enough in shabu shabu to deem this great, but would be back when considering shabu shabu as a destination.

0_1ZgnJJ2Vdwu0PPX3kH7Q.review_text: I have been having cravings since I went here two weekends ago; now I know why people go for the buffet option.  Good service, yummy and generous!

gm0V0GmBBlUlTqoZHsjWqw.review_text: I was craving shabu shabu (again) and my friend insisted that we come here because he claimed it was the best of the best.  We arrived really late on a Friday night, around 9:30pm and we were seated within five minutes.  My friend and I got a pot to ourselves, which was a first.  I'm accustomed to sharing pots.  The broth is flavored but with chicken stock, I think.  We opted for all-you-can-eat shabu, which included: -Beef -Chicken -Napa cabbage -Baby bok choy -Enoki Musroom -Two types of noodles: clear and a thin udon-like one  The beef came out nicely - it was lean and fresh.  All of the veggies were fresh and tasty.  They also customized your veggie platter upon request as well (ie. if you only want mushrooms, you can order it that way). Sadly, I was only able to polish off three plates of beef and two plates of veggies.  Quite impressively my friend hit an astounding 11 plates of beef but I think he was suffering after.  The service is quick and attentive.  The servers come around frequently to refill your plates and check on everything.  Cost per person is only $22.95 without the alcohol.  I don't know if I would say this is THE shabu place to go to but definitely good and worth checking out.

cGGjN-s3JSA-TOhQiFOEyg.review_text: After a 6 month hiatus, I finally came back to Happy Shabu Shabu on my Bday. It was everything I expected!!!  Food - Very comparable to Shabu House on Geary but less expensive.  Beef was thinly slice and fresh.  Broth was miso based.  3 different types of dipping sauce to choose from.  The noodles and veggie dish were also very good.  Noodles were nice and chewy.    $22.95 for all you can eat (chicken and beef) compared to $27.05 at Shabu House on Geary.   Will be back on a cold hungry day...

uvQCNhVsmgt1xU6HVKx9cA.review_text: Wow, there is nothing happy about this place. Food was ok, but oh my god the service/staff was T.E.R.R.I.B.L.E. It was no wonder there was only 2 other people in the entire restaurant on a Friday night!  There were 4 of us going to eat/drink here on a Fri night. Two of us ordered the all you can eat and drink special. Then one of my friends said I will order my own bottle of sake because I already ate. The waiter literally looked at me like I had just landed into his restaurant with a U.F.O. He said, he must sit by himself at the bar across to the restaurant if he wanted to do that. Hew would not even allow my friend to sit at the table across from us saying that he could not seat at a 4-top table. EVEN THOUGH THE RESTAURANT WAS EMPTY. He basically told my friend he must go sit at the bar if he wants to order anything unless he orders the "all you can eat/drink special". So my friend declined and was forced to watch us all eat and drink for an hour.  Now I must mention that during the entire course of our meal, the 2 straight-faced Japanese punk-rocker waiters were standing 10 feet from our table staring at our every move. Ensuring there is no sharing going on. They would literally stare at me ever time I would touch my cup or plate. We were trying to make the best of the situation and just laugh about it, but these guys literally persisted to watch over our shoulders the entire time. By this point there was no one else in the restaurant (approximately 10pm). So you can imagine how uncomfortable this can make you feel.  If there is a "happy" shabu shabu out there, this is not the one. This place should be called "Retarded Shabu Shabu", for how stupid these idiots were. They actually told us during our meal that people have been complaining on Yelp about them. HAHA that should've been a red flag right when we ordered.  Anyways, like I said. The food was O.K. But I'm sure there are a million other shabu's to go to that will not require getting the stink-eye during your entire meal.  **NOTE TO OWNER, get some new staff to actually smile at you and make you feel at home when patrons come to your restaurant. This city has way too many options for people to deal with that. Just some advice on p[possibly turning your restaurant around from crickets chirping in there on a Friday night.

Hqj0I26GCqGS42f5WjrJIA.review_text: Food quality: Have not tried yet.  Food portion: Have not tried yet.  Cleanliness: Average I guess. A lot of the tables were dirty because they were too lazy to clean them. & When they cleaned our table for us to be seated, they just collected the dishware & did a quick wipe, leaving the table wet with a mixture of water & what seemed to be soy sauce.  Atmosphere: Loud (people drunk from sake) & dim.  Service: Extremely poor; no greetings, no smiles. Waited about 5 minutes to be seated when the place was almost empty. Went in as a party of 6, 3 of us wanted the Beef Shabu only & the other 3 wanted the AYCE. They told us we can't do that because they don't want us to share so we asked if the other 3 can sit somewhere else so that we don't have contact with each other & they still say no even though there were a whole bunch of empty tables. Ridiculous.

xGDcXcscWQl_X0R3f1LIzw.review_text: Great experience at Happy Shabu Shabu. The service is not the most professional but very casual and friendly. We walked in on a Monday and were seated immediately. I was told by the waiter that weekdays are slow enough to walk in for a table but you should definitely get a reservation if you're coming in on the weekend.   I was a little intrigued by the individual hot pots because I'm used to sharing a single pot, but it's definitely handy to have your own pot. We did the "all you can eat" meal and was very satisified with the quality and quantity of food. Our waiter was very quick to bring out more veggies/meat when we were running low. They also have a vegetarian option for the vegetarians out there.   Overall it was a fun experience and we were extremely satisified (aka stuffed). I recommend Happy Shabu Shabu if you're in the area and craving Shabu Shabu. I will definitely be back here soon!

_YaBpCHDCx3vNjluUViHMQ.review_text: The experience and being able to cook what you want when you want is so much fun!!   I went on a date here and we did the unlimited eat and drink special. The steak is by far the best part of this place, and steer clear of the chicken, idk what the rules on cook time are for that.    The sauces are delicious,  especially the clear broth looking one..yummyyyyy.  Saki was hot and beers were cold.   Downside is the wait time (40 mins), because it's a small space :/

dTdltcr2EC5oMZ1rs795PA.review_text: all you can eat, all you can drink for $35?  it's pretty much a steal if you're with a group of guys who are prepared to feast and drink to your hearts content.  for groups of people, it's a little awkward b/c the seating is fairly spread apart.  but if you're loud, you wouldnt have a problem of talking over the spread out seating.  the pluses are that the ventilation is fairly adequate, and the service is very friendly and quick.  the meat is decent, and the sake is pretty low quality, but it will definitely get you drunk.  overall, it's a good place to come with a group of buddies and have loads of meat and drinks.

VXr8WfkHKUmNblmO5FNUxg.review_text: This place is FANTASTIC!  The ingredients are fresh and delicious, and they even let me and my friends in after hours for a nice private late-night dinner.  It was so awesome.  Kevin is the best!!!  Thank you Kevin!! ccvyDF_778McUn4h02A9cg.review_text: It's not authentic Japanese shabu shabu, but it's even better than that, the beef and vegetable here are fresh! I come here with my friend every week~

lUy6Lr9DoG_aHiicElbz9w.review_text: I came here for my birthday dinner and they charged me for my bday..after their promotional on their website said birthday free..also they messed up my reservation...I asked for ten seats they only had 7..My friends had to stand..also horrible customer service they only served us twice for all you can eat.not worth coming here..the older man that was supposedly the manager said he had to charge me no questions asked...bad promotions and fooled me and my friends

However, i am just giving them 4 stars because the quality of the vegetables are not as fresh as it used to be.  It was sad when the first owner sold the place. however, the new owner seems to try to do their best to maintain the quality.  I'll still keep coming back here.  This is my daughter's favorite shabu2 place. She loves to cook. I've been eating here almost once a month for 1.5 years.  It sooooooooooo goooooooooooooodddddddddd

-DmpYICjBii640Zny46cLQ.review_text: My friend told me beforehand that she was going to celebrate her bday here.  I told her that I was just gonna meet her towards the end of the dinner cause I read from other yelp reviews that all people of the party are required to buy the all you can eat special. I wasn't about to spend that much money, so I just met my friends at the restaurant towards the end of dinner to prevent the hassle.  We were gonna go out afterwards anyway.  So I get there, grab a chair, and sit with the group.  The bday girl gives me a sip of her beer..no big deal.  10 minutes later, the owner comes up to me and asks me if I'm eating or drinking.  I said, "no I'm not, but I might order a drink later."  He has the nerve to tell me that he saw me take a sip from my friends cup and that I had to pay $35 like everyone else.  I pretty much tell him, "no I'm not paying.  I'm not drinking with them.  I will buy my own drink at regular price if thats the case."  He gives up and says, "I'll pretend I didn't see you drink anything."  Later, my friends are offering me shots of sake and the owner looks at me and then over to them and shakes his head "no". 30 minutes later, the owner leaves our area and I'm just walking around our table, sitting, standing, talking to different people.  They were continuing to take shots while I just sat around and mingled.  As they are taking shots, my friend points to the owner standing at a distance from behind me.  I turn around and he was giving me the stink eye, shaking his head, and motioning his hand to the door to let me know that he wanted me to get out.  I turn around to him and I tell him firmly, "I AM NOT DRINKING. CALM DOWN!"    I don't understand the purpose as to why he felt the need to hassle me.  I know I didn't order any food or drink, which may have annoyed him.  BUT COME ON!!!  We had a party of over 10 people who all paid $35 each.  He was making his money for the night.  RIDICULOUS.  And what was even more frustrating was that they didn't even give the bday girl her "free meal".  According to the website, the bday person gets a free dinner if they bring a party of 6 people or more.  The bday girl's bday was at midnight and it was already 10pm.  2 freaking hours away and they weren't even the least bit flexible.    Based on service and hospitality alone, I will NEVER step foot inside this establishment again nor will I recommend any of my friends to come here.  You will get better service and better shabu at Shabu House in the Richmond.  I've never had anything like that happen to me at any restaurant.  I can't believe that they are even still in business with bullshit policy like that.  I can understand getting shitty service from a server, but if the owner is a dick, then what does that tell you on what kind of business he is running?  THIS PLACE SUCKS and it doesn't deserve any business with service like that.  RUDE. RUDE. RUDE.

3uJootQ876cXOb4Q2H39IQ.review_text: As a lover of shabu shabu, my relationship with Happy Shabu Shabu began with built-in biases.  This is a great place for shabu shabu with a slightly Korean twist.  For one thing, they offer kimchi (although they might have ended this tradition) as a banchan.  In addition to ponzu (soy sauce offset by tart citrus, often yuzu) and goma (sesame seed), they provide a fiery third dipping sauce.  The latter is made from spicy red chili paste and is a building block for many Korean dishes.  The beef is not Kobe, so let us get that out of the way.  It is cut ever so slightly thicker and most importantly, lacks the marbling.  On the positive side, it is less fatty.  I feel healthy when I eat it.  (Incidentally, that is why I love shabu shabu in general.)  The vegetarian platter that accompanies the meat comprises of the usual suspects:  napa cabbage, a few shiitake mushrooms, some enoki, cubes of tofu, and udon noodles.  In the broth floats ginseng root, which is another Korean variation.  The service is delightful.  Once upon a time, there was a Korean waitress who was simply the most adorable lady, but on my last visit, I was sad to hear that she was going to return to Korea.  Finally, the arrangement of the tables and chairs will take some getting used to.  It is unquestionably one of the most unique and awkward (especially for large parties) set-ups I have ever seen and taken part in.  I will try to describe it, but this is a case when a picture is optimal.  All of the tables and chairs are in rows, so that you cannot converse at a normal voice level with anyone other than the person sitting next to you.  To anyone else in your party, you will have to holler across the rows.  It gets weird.

hBKIfDc6WfgT2Chh8QqUaQ.review_text: Pretty good, bring your own booze, do your own cooking

Vk_HNTRnjXQCvgykBVxeyQ.review_text: ayce and drink sake and beer, sounds like a good time right?  It sure is, but just be warned, all you can drink is dangerous. Steven, the manager there is a real cool guy, jokes around with you, remembers certain customers and their drinking habits. But when he unleashes the secret mind eraser fire water, be forewarned, you will lose all recollection of anything that transpired over the course of this meal.  All that aside, food is pretty average, dipping sauces just ok. This place is perfect just to get hammered on the cheap and have a filling/decently satisfying meal. 3.5 stars, but I'll round up just from all the memories (or lack of) and stories that come out of this place.

qACeo5PPVyPJHWUf5L2Ewg.review_text: For the record I ate here maybe a year ago and it was OK.  I tried to go there last night with a friend a 2 small children about 6 and 7 years old.  I ordered 2 All you can eat adults and 2 kids meals.  The terrible waiter said if 1 person eats all you can eat then everyone has to eat all you can eat.  I said these are 2 kids are you serious?  He said yup that is the rule.  WOW the concept of customer first has gone out the window with this place.  Looking at a few other reviews by my friends I am not alone with the TERRIBLE service in the place.  I'm glad I didn't eat there.  You would think that at 7:30pm on a Sunday with 3 customers they would have wanted some business.....

lzKkZs1pJUpY8_7IU13_Ig.review_text: The staff was friendly and pretty hands-off, the price (~$13 for a regular pot more than enough for one person) is reasonable, never too crowded thus this place is perfect if you want a relaxed and laid back atmosphere.  The ingredients are fresh and of good variety.

Ce9PlB0lqKri4diijzc7WA.review_text: Rated no.1 for their sanitation guidelines Rated no.1 for making sure your beef plate is always filled. Quality of food is above average shabu places I've dined at. My hunnie ate so much- he looked like a preggo- and that makes me a happy camper- for that- you get all 5 stars :)

jR2mMjKjwroZkPA70btlYw.review_text: I went here for my b-day dinner and I really enjoyed myself.  The food was fresh and simple and I really enjoyed the hot pot cooking experience.  The way some of the dining stations are set up actually accommodate slightly large groups nicely, there were 13 of us and it worked out well.  Half of us sat on one side and half on the other side, so it wasn't easy to chat with the people on the opposite side of the station, but it works out anyway!  I feel bad because I don't remember the name of the girl who served us but she was extremely friendly and attentive!  Oh and they took $14 or $15 dollars off my meal because it was my birthday and we were in a group of 6+.

817ErNQeMjw-jfgVLZH6MQ.review_text: Hangover buster? Sickness remedy? So I'm no Shabu aficionado but this place isn't half bad. My girlfriend has been talking up Shabu Shabu for months. So I gave in and I kind of think its a sort of super Pho. Regardless, the quantity and quality of the beef and veggies were sufficient. The sauces were lacking. The two of us each got the all you can eat (which there was no need for). The service was a bit laggy, and there weren't many folk in the place. At the end of the meal I had a full belly and a vat of hot tasty broth in front of me. Long story short, we were feeling shitty and this was some feeling good food. I'll be back, order less exccesively, and the world will be at peace.

c8NiksyAjCWqI3EzjU-2uw.review_text: The beef was great. For sure I will go there again but there are two thing I don't like there. They need a bigger place cuz is kinda small and the is too cold in there. Even with these two reason I will still go back to eat here. Cuz there beef is really good.

y27w9lGFEQEMrOeLZ5bB_Q.review_text: happy shabu shabu....  left my tummy UNHAPPY... that is all.  PS- try not to shaBU BU in your pants after eating. hotel miyako has nice clean bathroom at jtown.

HdaLqZjroe6IMPci055BDA.review_text: I came here for a friend's birthday which was a nice treat.  A nicer treat was us not having to pay for her dinner because it was free!  =]] Yay to the birthday promotion!  We all got different sorts of meat and from what I heard the beef plate was the best.  The chicken was too dry and the seafood platter was bland.  I loved that our meal came with a HUGE plate of veggies!  Honestly, that's my favorite part...shabu-ing the veggies!  So good.  I almost ordered extra veggies but the waiter told me to hold off on it until my plate came.  Thanks! Tired and sleepy the SO and I manage to still polish off 4 + plates each. you would think the food looks really light and not so filling, but think again..... you will feel lazy as a rock once you are done.   Not anything out of the ordinary,  but still good and not as expensive as I expected it to be.

EKdyI4jpUF29YtPkKiCtcg.review_text: my next 2 reviews: a NEW FROYO PLACE IN THE MARINA & a japanese izakaya, again, IN THE MARINA...  ***  i usually don't like the whole "all you can eat" deals. sure, its well worth every penny but most of the time the food quality just sucks... ever since i was a kid, i don't really remember going to a whole lot of buffets ...  it's all about the quality people!!! i think i started going to buffets more often during college ... but happy shabu shabu? i'm FOR IT.  manna (a all you can eat poor quality korean restaurant in LA which everyone seems to love...http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_­search?userid=EKdyI4jpUF29YtPkKiCtcg&q=manna&fsid=­ikrOOMmXSR0OEMhoDE-bRg) & todai .. YUCK!  you won't believe in what i ate prior to happy shabu shabu ... for breakfast, i had a bowl of unagi don (yes, i prepared it myself!) with spam & eggs, bowl of cereal, mango smoothie (yes, i made it myself!) then went to the giants game (box seats baby! woohoo! BUT IT WAS SUCHA LAME ASS GAME.. 9-1? wth?) and ate endless nachos, 10 chicken wings, cheese and crackers, fries and fishchips (shoot, you're in the suite, of course you'll end up stuffin yourself!) for lunch, and 2 hours after the game, i came here and lo and behold stuffed my fat face with 7 1/2 plates worth of shabu shabu meat...)  $23.95 for all you can eat shabu shabu (veggies, chicken & beef) ... we all know the works ... all includes carrot, mushroom, lettuce, etc etc) but this place also gives you 3 lil potstickers.. MMM. it was GOOD...   OR  you can pay $35 for all you can eat shabu shabu and drinks (alcohol) silly... i came here with over 20 people, almost 1/2 of the people from LA ... it's always times like this when i often wonder why i left LA ... hanging out with my LA guy friends, the memories are priceless .. good times, good times!  you won't believe! i ate 7 1/2 plates worth of shabu shabu plates worth of beef ... and here i am writing still stuffed and am craving it every second !!! (take a peek of my foto!)  the quality of the meat was actually really good, no cheapies, but their chicken was so-so... overall, the food was great, delicious and fresh...  i really like the fact how you get your own lil seating with 3 different types of sauces...  opened for dinner only!

dviPtjXu-AzbefzWExaxGA.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu is my first choice for shabu shabu in SF and happens to have the lowest all-you-can-eat/drink prices that I've seen in the city.  I've been here with friends from Japan, so it's been Shabu-Expert Approved (level of expertise determined by yours truly).  The seating is arranged in rows facing each other across an aisle that servers can walk through easily without having to reach over your head to put down a plate of food.  This makes for an awkward layout, but after experiencing the cramped all-you-can-eat madness at other places, it's a welcome change.  There are long picnic tables out front to accommodate larger groups.  In addition to unlimited plates of meat, they provide large platters of veggies and noodles (my favorite are the white noodles... I think they're yam noodles?).  Each person gets their own pot and 3 different dipping sauces. The spicy sauce is the crowd favorite but I prefer the sesame. Service tends to be pretty good, and the owner comes out and interacts a lot with the customers.  There's a giant Safeway lot across the street but you do run the risk of getting towed.  One con is that I have had trouble in the past contacting the restaurant. There was one weekday night when I called literally 8-10 times and never got an answer.

C_mRoBu87_J7QWQGPcYaGQ.review_text: This is a decent choice for shabu shabu. Food is good, service is good. Nothing outstanding but decent all the way around.

H7s0wAZUKc0V1nahMABPPQ.review_text: My first thought was "are they going to put some broth or base ingredients in the water?"  But after some careful thought, I realized they don't want mask the natural flavors of the meats and veggies by using unnecessary spices.  Is this a fact?  Can I substantiate this claim?  Nope.  But it sounds good and makes sense right? :D  Each person gets their own hot pot.  You don't have to reach over other people or put your meat in the pot only to have one of your friends swipe it as soon as it is cooked.    All You Can Eat $22.95 Beef, Chicken and Vegetables.  Dumplings were included.  Fantastic deal.  But no lamb and the chicken was just okay...  The beef, however, was fresh and very tender.    I'm gonna tell my friends about this place!

IGkZa0eanufzVv9FR7kSUg.review_text: Of Mums, Happy, and Shabusen as the three main contenders for shabu shabu in the Japantown area, Happy is the most affordable of them all. They have an all you can eat option, but The AYCE price is actually about the same as Mums, so for that option we'd probably opt for Mums over Happy. Instead, we come to Happy for the single servings for health reasons. Happy can't really decide whether it's Chinese, Korean, or Japanese, so you kind of get a mix of all three in terms of music genre being played, TV show airing, and type of sauce. I'd say that of the three, Happy has my least favorite sesame sauce, but it does have the option of a hot sauce...(thinking that's less of the Japanese and more of the fusion).  You get your own pot and the service is minimal, but it's nice when you don't want to do dishes that night or fried foods--just drop by Happy Shabu and boil'er-up! :)

Dj77pkw_EZJvR-F4RIf_BQ.review_text: all you can eat and drink for $34.95.    imagine what sort of crowd that brings in to this restaurant?  ...EXTREMELY obnoxious college freshmen who don't know how to hold their alcohol.    the set up is already awkward...every person has their own broth so you're pretty much sitting side by side with your entire party.  if you have more than 2 people, you'll have to sit at two different tables facing each other.  they're pretty far...so you'll have to yell to be able to speak to the other people in your party.    so the party of 8 college freshmen next to us...were yelling and screaming... DRUNK...about their sex lives and other things i just don't want to hear about.  i'm sure the rest of the block heard their conversation also.  anyhoo, can't really take away from a restaurant's overall review because of their customers...so onto the pertinent stuff eh?  the broth was probably the worst broth i've ever had at a shabu shabu restaurant.  you don't have a choice...and whatever they did serve is not even traditional.  there was no seaweed...and the broth wasn't clear.  maybe it was chicken broth or something?    the meat was ok...we asked the server if they had kobe beef and she had no idea what we were talking about.  so we just ordered the regular beef.  haha.  it had a good marble...and the portion size was decent.    the sauces were way off...the sesame one was super grainy...the regular ponzu sauce tasted strange...like it was fermented or something.  the spicy sauce was probably the best one out of the 3.    the plate of veggies and noodles were plentiful...probably the highlight of the meal.  i was stoked to see 2 different types of noodles.  the service was mediocre...in the beginning, i think they were super stressed.  they forgot our drinks...the people at the table in front of us were basically doing jumping jacks to get the server's attention.  and i had to hear another server rant about how she is not japanese.  argh.  so all in all...the food and service were just ok...the ambiance is absolutely ridiculous...but it's local...so 3 stars is about right.

iOpvXcAv2EyUV-E_rO_PFg.review_text: I was going to start off saying that this place was horrible.  But then I collected myself and decided not to totally trash this place.  But all in all, this place wasn't good.  I didn't leave Happy!  We were the only ones in the place the whole time.  I guess it was early - 6pm and we thought we could do the early bird special, all you can eat, before 6:30pm.  The happy hour is 15% off anything...so not much of a special really.    The hostess/waitress was really nice but it just seemed like they were hurting for business.  The sesame sauce was bland, the spicy chili sauce and ponzu weren't bad but the condiments looked old and dried up.  We got the chicken and beef special.  The beef was decently fresh but was the fatiest cut I'd ever seen.  And the chicken looked and tasted old.  I left most of it.  The good thing about the veggies was that they offer bok choy in addition to the standard napa cabbage that you get at most places.  The space is pretty cool though.   It looked like a good place to invite a big group since they have big long tables and each person gets their own burner which is a huge plus.  I don't think I'll go back there - everything just tasted old.  I'd rather stick to Shabu-sen in j-town.  I wish I hadn't gotten so turned off by the place, I might have had a better appetite for the yogurt place just down the street.

ChKHMb5xCCjO99vac3MhnQ.review_text: We found this place on a guy's nite out when we just wanted to DRINK, EAT, and DRINK some more.  Happy Shabu Shabu delivered.  The meat is fresh, the service is pleasant, and the staff is great.  Stephen is always there and a very nice man.  If you are drinking, he will go around and drink with you (occasionally) (don't test him b/c he just may make you some HOLY WATER which will make you scream "HOLY SH!T" :).  His server, Serena, is great too and has a great attitude.  Don't let the petite girl fool you.  This girl can drink and can boat race with the best of them.  Beer only please.  I liked this place so much that my wife and I decided to have our rehearsal dinner here and rented out the whole restaurant.  Everyone had a blast, and Stephen was super accomodating in helping us make sure the evening went smoothly and everyone got to eat what they wanted.  He even went out of his way to help us create a special menu.    In summary, Happy Shabu Shabu t is a great venue for social gatherings and I truly appreciate the quality of service here.

gfHSZbKC2bjb4CtXpafAKg.review_text: great stuff.. my very first having shabu shabu..beef was great.. the sauces they had were good.. prices were ok for the amount of food I had.. and the place wasn't crowded, although it's not a big place.. only drawback is the seating.. they seat you next to each other with your own hotpot.. then if you have more ppl, they sit across from you on another table.. there is a walkway inbetween for the waitresses.. overall, I would totally come back!

a7x7C5FvlRYcO2EhhY0jsA.review_text: Pretty poor quality meat.  Too lean and tastes freezer burned/grainy.  Sesame sauce is bland and watery, ponzu tastes like they try to do it homemade and put too much sake in it, and the spicy sauce is way overpowering.  I suppose it'll suffice if you're just concerned about stuffing your face with the all-you-can-eat option, but Kufuya down Geary is a better option for that IMO.  If you want GOOD shabu shabu go to Shabuway in San Mateo/Mtn View.  They are Japanese and use wagyu, the sauces are great and balanced, and the quality is consistently excellent.  For literally a couple bucks more you can have 2 large plates of superior beef!  (Get the "premium" [dinner only] - it's worth it)

QMkbjQtasAn4ZLaDb6ZNTw.review_text: Happy Shabu beats out Mum's and Shabu Sen for the best Shabu Shabu in J-Town (Despite that the location is closer to Western Addition, at Eddy and Fillmore). For essentially the same price, the quality of meat as well as the thickness is much better than Shabu Sen or Mum's. In addition, the vegetables and noodles (2 kinds) that accompany your meat selection are a lot more generous and varied. It's nice to know that you're getting some good veggies in your diet when you're pounding a giant plate of beef. In addition to the standard miso and ponzu sauce, they also give you a spicy korean sauce. Finally, for dessert, you also get a complimentary mochi ice cream. The only draw back is that the spacing and seating is uncomfortable. The tables allow very little space for your legs to duck under, and if you have over a party of two, you're either all sitting in a long row or face to face but with a giant space between your tables, making conversation difficult.

tBYIXjYx_3hnbq3cIqH02g.review_text: I was really bummed.  I knew that it was a long shot, but it was hoping it would be different.  The place was empty when we entered.  That should of been a sign, but what could we do?  The meat was just okay, but everything else was well "bleh".  The sauces were watered down, and they didn't have udon!  Just an okay experience.  The place was clean, but the layout was a bit odd.  You kind up staring at the other guests at the opposite table so somewhat odd.  This place was not horrible, but there are better places in the city to have shabu shabu.

5jq_1AngK0Q4eJqk-dS0Kg.review_text: My first experience with Shabu... oh my! I wasn't sure what to expect of this random place in Japantown, but I had the time of my life.  We did the All-You-Can-Eat and Drink for $32 per person. Such a deal! You get a huge platter of veggies and beef or chicken and your own boiling pot! You get three great sauces to dip your food it too! Beyond the food, which is obviously not 4 star, but still good, the all you can drink is the real star of this show! It is all you can drink beer and sake. Dangerous! We were only there 2 hours but we all left quite sloppy! The manager, Steven, was hilarious and made our trip there extra special! Watch out for his "Fire Water"

UtzOKXhjjvP5iPyn4VSK2w.review_text: Came back here last night with a party of six people. One person in our party is vegetarian. The waiter agreed to allow five of us to pay all-you-can-eat and allow our vegetarian friend to pay for just a single vegetable shabu shabu.  When we brought this up to the manager he disagreed with the manager and then spoke to us disrespectfully. It would have been fine if the manager told us we could not do it in a polite manner but his exact words were:  "Sorry I am the manager. I make the rules. He's just a waiter. If he wants to pay the difference you guys can do it."  WOW. We were stunned to say the least. Keep in mind this is an establishment that one person in party frequented numerous times a month....and this is how we are spoken to?  We were planning on buying lots of alcohol as well and they were going to nitpick with us over a $10 difference?  Ridiculous. It's not about the money, it's about how you treat customers.  Avoid this place. The manager is terrible and needs to learn respect.

0HwJtI06DB1ZPvQRNyCx1Q.review_text: This place is great if you have a group of people and are looking for a fun dinner. I came with a group of 12 and the service was quick, attentive. Food, beer, and sake were never low (and we were continuously depleting all of them).   I got the vegetarian all-you-can-eat/drink (2 hour max) and was really happy with the variety of food. There were glass noodles, flour(?) noodles, enoki and shiitake mushrooms, 2 types of squash, broccoli, bok choy, fried and raw tofu, and faux ham and shrimp. The beer and sake were good too, although I don't know what brand.   There were 3 dipping sauces, although i still found the food to be not as flavorful as I would have thought. But maybe I was doing it wrong.   I thought the all-you-can eat was only worth it because of the unlimited beer and sake. I could not even finish a full plate of the veggies/noodles/veggie meats so for the food only it would have been a waste.   Great for groups and celebrations. Only get the all-you-can-eat and drink if you plan to drink.

shkSqT17XGkSc64frKFCbw.review_text: Don't go here. Unless you're doing an investigative news report on worst customer experiences ever or hostile work environments.

CXLyd1ENz6bGg6JRtkdpTg.review_text: This place gets a solid three stars, because it doesn't have to be authentic to be good.  Most shabu shabu places get away with charging a lot of money for hot pot, and this place isn't too bad in that regard.  The choices on the menu are lacking, but all I wanted to satisfy my deep craving of shabu shabu was a side of good beef.  They delivered.  I had to really doctor up the broth to my liking, which bummed me out, but the vegetables were okay.  I was hoping for more mushrooms, but they literally only give you one.   The ambience was lackluster, as I had a trashy episode of Jersey Shore on the wall to taunt me in between bites.  Regardless, if you want an amazing shabu shabu experience, I'd recommend another place.  If you just want to satisfy the craving and save a few bucks, this place is perfectly adequate.

kCMw6ZtC9weRMUjSqs-P9A.review_text: Been to this shabu place a few times. I would say its a new and still relatively unknown place compared to Mums or Shabu House.  But this little place is great.  The beef is freshly sliced and not frozen like some other places.   22.95 for all you can eat is a bargain. They have recently added miso and spicy miso to their menu of broths ( it was plain hot water before).  Great selection of veggies and you get your own pot! Just kinda wonder what happened to the dumplings they used to give out.  Dipping sauces are fairly good.  You get 3, sesame, hot/spicy, and ponzu.  I only use the hot/spicy and ponzu as the sesame is pretty bland.        One gripe..the seating is not that great.  Since you get your own pot, you lose the intimacy if you go with your friends.  You have to face strangers while you eat and even eating with just 3 people is pretty difficult.      All in all..the food is really good.  Service could be a little improved on since there were only 2 waitresses running around serving the entire place.     There is also all you can eat and drink for 34.95 but not really worth it unless you have a huge belly for booze and food.  for 12 bux more..you have to drink  at least 2 of the large beers to break even.   Will be back!....

kUXozMM-hvcSW87bM21RMw.review_text: I just stuffed myself with all you can eat shabu shabu!   I've been here a few times with friends, and we always have to roll out of the restaurant after dinner. For $22.95, you can get all you can eat shabu shabu. And we definitely eat all we can eat.   I always get the beef now. I tried the chicken once, but boiled chicken just doesn't taste that great. They used to just have plain hot water to cook your food, but now they have miso and spicy miso broth. I like their ponzu and spicy dipping sauces. The sesame sauce just doesn't seem to have that much flavor to it.   The only thing I don't like is their table setup. There are rows of 2 or 5. And the rows face each other. So if you have a party of 5 and there's another party of 5, your party would be in one row staring at the other party. Kind of weird to be staring at strangers when you're eating dinner. And you can't talk to your own people unless you yell down the row.   I still haven't tried their $34.95 all you can eat & drink dinner. I think I'd rather not barf up all that meat I just consumed.

6CqjM5LYyumiaNnGU4M6dg.review_text: John is the shit. He is awesome.  Other than that food was excellent! Fresh beef.   Unlimited refills on meats,veggies, saki, and fun!!!!!  Awesome.  Btw I'm drunk now.

x4dMlJWPH-iaNqdDoRwmqQ.review_text: If you decide to go to Happy Shabu Shabu, be ready to be selfish. You get your own hot pot! Therefore, I'd suggest to bring even numbers of friends and sit across from each other (unless you like to sit next to one another in a row). I was extremely impressed with the cleanliness of the place!  Skip the chicken/beef combo and just get the beef. Each person gets 3 dipping sauces (sesame, soy sauce, and hot sauce), veggies and rice.

PtNR9MglVVVYsj4XrqTZqA.review_text: This review is long overdue. "Happy Shabu Shabu" is my favorite place...  I've been going here for the past 3 years.  Before I moved to San Francisco, I didn't even know what Shabu Shabu WAS, now I can't imagine my life without it....  I still remember the first time I wandered into "Happy Shabu Shabu". I didn't know how or what I was supposed to do with the pile of food and bubbling cauldron placed in front of me. I remember dropping a piece of meat into the water and staring at it. I wasn't sure how long it should cook or what order I was supposed to cook this stuff. I was perplexed and intrigued. I just remember leaving the experience feeling like I had discovered something amazing and knowing that I needed to return   I've been to many Shabu Shabu places in the city since then and this one beats them all.  I will explain why...  1. THE PRICE. $11.99 for the veggie shabu shabu and $14.99 for the beef. The portions are huge! There are noodles, vegetables (Cabbage, carrots, broccoli, cauliflower, spring onions, tofu, bok choy, mushrooms..etc) I always leave feeling completely full and happy. I've had shabu shabu that cost more money and I still felt hungry at the end. This is the best deal you're going to find in the city.   2. THE SAUCES! I've noticed most Shabu Shabu places have 2 sauces. A ponzu and a sesame. Happy Shabu Shabu takes it to the next level with 3 sauces. That third sauce is what does it. It's a mildly spicy and tasty chili sauce mix. It goes really well with the Sesame/peanut sauces. The blend of those 2 sauces working together kicks the whole experience to the next level.   3. INDIVIDUAL POTS. You have a warm bubbling pot all to yourself. I've done the group Shabu Shabu thing at other places and I didn't enjoy fishing around in the pot searching for my veggies amidst other people's cooking foods. It was stressful and annoying. I like having my own pot and cooking at my own pace. I feel relaxed when I'm there and I know I can just take my time.  4. STAFF - They're all warm, friendly and efficient. When I come in, they already know my order and they're sliding the tray with everything I need in front of me. The sauces all lined up, the little bowl, the utensils and chopsticks. Little jar of garlic and chives. The pot begins to boil and before I know it I'm happy. If I could eat here, every night. I would! It's really THAT good.   That being said, the seating arrangement is a bit awkward for groups of four. You sit across from each other with a big divide in-between you. This space allows the server to adjust your pot temperature and refill the miso broth. Unfortunately as a result, You have to speak loudly to hear each other. If you have a big group, they can accommodate you. Just make sure you call in a reservation in advance. I usually sit at the bar. It's easiest for 2 people.

MpiVWeCeMiIxf7oOtHmP7g.review_text: 2.5 stars  It's not often that a person from the south bay can say something like this in relation to SF, but: there is a place like this in San Jose, and it's better.  Shaburi Shabu Shabu in Japantown SJ is better....fyi!  About $15 per person for standard beef shabu shabu that comes with veggies.  Good portion size, no complaints there.  However, the dipping sauces here are really lacking.  There was a peanut sauce that tasted like liquefied peanuts...literally inedible.  There was something that was basically diluted sirracha.  Tasty, but no points for originality.  The final sauce tasted like soy sauce and mirin/sake.  Boooring.  When I have shabu shabu, a good dipping sauce is KEY.  Something like yuzu soy sauce or a tasty hot sauce or a peanut sauce that doesn't taste like circus peanuts.  There is a cool option of all you can eat + drink (meaning sake and beer!) that is kinda intriguing..mostly for the all you can drink part.  Also, there were people at a table near us who were getting ready to leave and someone who works here wouldn't stop talking to them!  It was obvious the guy was bothering them, and as soon as he had to leave for a minute to check up on some work stuff, they got the hell outta there fast.  For the price, I don't think I'd' come back unless I were checking out all you can drink.  I'll stick to my south bay shabu shabu, thanks!

6Mi5woaSUh6gGcLnzLYNfg.review_text: Not a bad shabu place at all.  FOR THE PRICE, EXACTLY WHAT YOU EXPECT.  I did the all you can eat here, and it was good.  The BEEF however was not as marbled other places I've been.  But having said that, it allows me to eat more meat cause it's not as greasy.  If you come here you have to try the soup base with the in house special spicy sauce.  The owner makes it himself and each batch takes a couple of weeks to make.  Pretty damn good.  Very Chinese kind of spicy aroma.

Vgh-CjwAl4tFleP39OdzaA.review_text: Good price (for just the beef shabu $14.95) for the AYCE $22 & the quality of the food was decent -- the veggies I got were super fresh & the beef was good. You get your own individual pot which is nice (vs other shabu places where there's a community pot). I guess this is better for folks who are vegetarian/etc so they don't need to share their pots/soup/etc.   Service was good at first, but the place gets packed pretty quickly and the staff was stretched thin trying to cover all the tables. I'd recommend going earlier to avoid the rush :)

UX6XnH7LtAb7mdUi4kWg2A.review_text: Happy Shabu Shabu was not crowded at all for my first visit on a Tuesday night. We sat right down in a row with an electric stove burner in front of each of us, and I temporarily got over my hangup of sitting across from an empty space. We ordered some sake (natch), two veggie plates, and one beef plate. If they had offered veggie appetizers, rolls, or other such option more substantial than soup, I would have ordered that in addition.   I'm glad they didn't; two plates piled high with fresh tofu, cabbage, mushrooms, bok choy, carrots, and "veggie ham" (not listed on the menu) arrived, hot on the heels of a plate full o' raw beef (gag), three pots of hot, mysterious broth (miso?), and three sauces for each of us (sesame, spicy, and something sweet with which you were supposed to accompany green onions).  I tried to stagger the food dropped into the pot to cook appropriately, but to no avail: Everything was mega-cooked before the server returned to turn off the burners. But even then it was delicious. However, charging $12 for a veggie plate that probably cost $2.50 to assemble when I have to cook and season it myself is a little outrageous, especially when they don't stock any to-go containers (what restaurant does that?!).   UPON MY RETURN: I'll bring plenty of money, an extra-empty tummy, and my own Tupperware.

WiuXmGs_28M9qf5JZt3gJw.review_text: food was good but kinda pricey.

TMLVzNYs-zwwREudyvI08A.review_text: This place is pretty good.  The food looked and tasted very fresh.  I had the "God Fearing, Tax Paying Good American" plate (steak, and lots of it).  The staff was super nice and attentive.  And how cool is it that you get your own pot and cooking utensils? Very cool I tell you. You never know which of your closest friends might have a case of the cooties.  The only thing keeping this place from being 4 stars is the fact that they didn't have a liquor license. I'm sorry, but I really like to have some drinky drinky with my shabu shabu.

Oesvxmmtg7YyTH2ma8pmmg.review_text: This place is great. Better than Mums in my opinion. All you can eat and drink is less than Mums at $35. You get 3 sauces to dip and your own plate of meat. If you do alcohol, each person gets their own sake. Real cool for a group or even a night out with someone special.

LU7ikPXZ5R8tv4oNQZQkKw.review_text: This place has the best service for an all you can eat and drink Shabu place in the city.  I've been to pretty much all of them and this one by far destorys everyone else.  Shabu house has too many sake bottles shoved up their asses so they have a hard time serving you.  We went with a party of 20 people and in the end everyone was completely trashed.  But the people stil kept bringing alcohol and food with no hesitation.  The Shabu was pretty good.  The meats are good.  I really liked the chicken.  They just need better broth.  I am definitely going back.

AtmjvEIEcuTFv8Ucdmo6UQ.review_text: Food was ok. The beef was very good  the service is not good at this place.... Just mediocre... And the place is not even busy...

CAQv3QQHUasQNtN-HEldAw.review_text: I came here the other night with some friends that usually get drunk at this bar, but decided to get out for a change cause it was one of the regulars birthday's, and since birthday's only come once a year, I guess it was reason to celebrate, and hot pot fit the bill, cause who doesn't want some warm food with good company on a day like your birthday?  One of the things that separates this hot pot restaurant from the rest is the table space. Each place setting has its own hot pot station, so you can cook and eat your own food without having others double dip their chopsticks into your pot. The all you can eat here isn't bad either, why get one plate of razor thin beef when you can get three?  And I wouldn't go for the chicken either. Stick to the beef, and ask for the lamb if any's available. And have a blast with the dipping sauces--soy, spicy, and peanut. They're fun to mix and match.

UzT83K14kPyEpA7jQbL_GA.review_text: I had an awesome time here, the all you can eat and drink special cant be beat. I'll definitely be back here for another round

H8q4N1DNgogAxo3T22x1bw.review_text: Me & friends went there saturday.  Service is good.  Most of us ordered beef shabu, and one order of beef and chicken.  Beef taste better tho.   Sesame dipping sauce is not as good as Shabu way They charged us 20% tips on our bill eventho we were only party of 5.   I still like Shabuway better.

0EAP2Ixw6DWXWkxpWcafWw.review_text: This was my first experience with 'shabu shabu' cuisine. The food was fresh, the restaurant was clean. I'm not sure that I'm all that into shabu shabu to be honest. The waitress didn't really instruct us on how to eat the meal, which honestly needs some directions. It would also be cool if you could control the temperature of your pot. Not a bad deal though, you get a ton of food for the money.

AHLGwiyzX4CY_9Y46IpPYQ.review_text: I would NEVER go to this restaurant again!  Rude service,bad foods(I think the shrimps are the frozen shrimps from Costco).The manager is the rudest person I've  ever met,and this is the worst dining experience I've ever had.By the way,they should change the name to "Unhappy Shaby Shabu".

ftqKNw6BbcEqT6eQCDzupg.review_text: Compared to Shabu Shabu on Geary, this place is just ok. Food is about the same quality as most shabu places but they only had one choice of soup. Maybe it was the really bad company I had that ruined this particular shabu experience (I was with a group of accountants i didn't really know, and apparently the only one who chose an occupation based on my passion for it and not for money).   The crowd gets really Asian and rowdy on late nights, which is fine, but I like to dine where I don't feel like I'm in a Young and Dangerous (Goo wak jai) movie. Chinese peeps, you know what I'm talking about.   Service is fast and efficient though, so plus for that. Overall, nothing really stands out about this place. Oh, and the way they set up the tables seems kind of odd when you're eating inside with a big group. Everyone is either too close together (if you're at the counters), or too far apart (when you're at the tables).   P.S. The bathroom was pretty funky....=/

5XO4iBD2JlZIoym9fDMV6A.review_text: First time stop in here. Didnt wait as they had table tops available with your very own pot. Ordered the beef, comes with vegis and noodles.  The sauces are ok, but not my favorite. and the tofu and vegis are just enough to satisfy the palet. The beef I ordered was a very good amount, and the cuts were very nice and thin. good quality beef considering it was not kobe.   Service was good, TV screens to watch football, and decent atmosphere.   nice!

0UAkDCb7L3M5VAWwKFaD2w.review_text: Definitely the best in quality when it comes to shabu shabu in the city.  This place is clean.  Clean enough to eat off the table.  The service is very good here, very courteous, very polite.  They even come by and scoop the cooked blood that sits on top of the water.  The beef here is very good quality, very fresh and perfectly marbled.  Even though I prefer a little more fat.  However, I would say that for most people it would be perfect.  The down side is that they need to start serving Asahi.  Everyone serves Sapporo.  Why?  Asahi is much much better.

tOLSima4VTPxKuB7j88L8g.review_text: This place has the rudest customer service I have ever experienced.  We came here for a birthday party w/6 people.  We had a reservation (more on this later).  Upon arrival, the place was completely empty.  We were promptly seated at two "counters" that faced each other.  Soon after, we were told, rudely, that we had to move to another table.  No reason was given, but we didn't mind as we hadn't started eating, so whatever, we moved.  The waitress gave us no help in moving, didn't even pick up our water cups for us.  We had to do it ourselves.  But onwards.   Before taking our order, our waitress, a younger looking Asian girl that looked and talked like a rececnt immigrant, bluntly informed us that we would have to vacate our table and finish eating in exactly one hour because the restaurant had another reservation for the table (nevermind that we too, had a reservation and that the place was completely empty during the entire time we were there).  I was rather dumbfounded by this "request", but since we had to meet some other friends at a bar in about an hour, I didn't protest too much and just said "fine".  Our food was served promptly, and the food itself was ok (it's pretty hard to mess up boiling water, uncooked meat and vegetables).  When we finished with our food, the waitress came back, and rudely told us (and I quote) "It's been one hour, you guys need to leave now.  Can I bring check?".  At this point I was getting a little irritated, but because everyone was basically done and it was time for us to get on with our evening, I said (rather irritated), "yes, fine."  Upon getting the check we noticed that one of our meals (for the birthday person) hadn't been comp'd (as their website promises for parties of "6 AND More").  I brought this up with our waitress, and she rudely responded, "you need seven people for that".  I said, "No, on your website it says 6 AND More..." and then pulled out my Iphone and their website to prove my point.  Her response, in broken English and a blank stare was, "Yes.  7 people."  This was the last straw, so I demanded to speak with her manager, as the last time I checked "AND" is an INCLUSIVE word, which meant 6 people was all that was required to qualify for hte deal.  The waitress went back and upon return, told us that she had taken care of the free birthday meal.  However, upon further review of the bill, I now noticed that they tacked on an 18% Gratuity charge.  So yeah, the birthday person's meal was free, but now I had to pay an additional 18% gratuity for a place with piss poor service that didn't deserve a tip!  I complained again, only to get dumb stares in return from our waitress so I finally just gave up and paid the 18% gratuity since we were now running late and I didn't want to stick around and argue with these people for the rest of the night.  I slapped down my credit card, she took it back, charged it and returned it.  I signed my name and gave them NO additional tip, then started flipping the receipt over (as I usually do).  As soon as I did that, the waitress grabs the receipt from my hand, flips it over again while I'm still sitting at the table, notices that I gave them no additional tip, YANKS the receipt from me, and gives me an evil look, then storms away. No thank you for your business, have a good night, nothing.  Just up and left.  This place is far from being Happy.  And I certainly was NOT Happy. NEVER coming to this place again.  The staff are Shabu Shabu Nazis.

T6zcfyO8eR2Py9V_bK_K4w.review_text: My company had a dinner/birthday celebration here last night.  At first walking in, the place is empty @ 8 pm.  But we were a party of 20+, so we literally occupied half of the restaurant.    Like most reviewers stated, the layout is very awkward and not much conversation will be made.  But if you get the all you can eat/drink option, loads of sake and beer later, you will definitely be shouting across the room.  I really dig the fact that the beef was freshly sliced on a deli slicer every 10 minutes!  The beef had no marbling,some fat, and was thin enough to ensure quick cooking time.  But the freshness...wow.  One of the servers working is super pushy into getting everyone to drink!!!  I was DD and I had shot of sake and glass of beer, but noooooo I was forced to drink......boo there for no respect for responsibility!    Oh yeah, the spicy sauce they got is SOOOOOOO good!  However, the broth is instant, there's a bucket where they take a scoop of broth paste and just add hot water, mix it, and then pour it back into our hot pots.  Left a super nasty MSG aftereffect...but then again, the rest of the folks were too drunk to notice.  Overall, fun, price is right, and a lot of happy people went home drunk (or continued drinking).

JjtQ1txoSd69pSwUPsWxcA.review_text: We came to happy shabu shabu for an engagement party and there was at least 15 of us. The restaurant was clean, the waitress nice, and since there didn't seem to be anyone else in the restaurant is was easy to seat us next to each other at the little cooking stations.  I'd never yet tried the shabu experience and I was left feeling underwhelmed. The chicken didn't seem as fresh as the beef combo, and despite the fact we were cooking the food ourselves, the meal overall was pretty bland. I did dump all sorts of seasoning and sauces on my meat and veggies, and still felt that it tasted like sopping wet tastless food. I also do not think they provide enough noodles.  My boyfriend was glad that we didn't get the all you can eat, because although he was still hungry after eating everything, he wasn't sure if he would have enjoyed more blandness. I think shabu is pure novelty, and that's what you pay for. If you want something tasty, perhaps try something else.

bGrNXi8Uu-AZdjrXkpB4Zg.review_text: Have to give this place only 4 stars. Sorry. I am a shabu shabu lover myself but if I dine at a shabu spot please don't put a stop sign in front of me. Pull it out and give me more stuff to shabu in. This place only had 4 options...2 Veg and 2 Meat eater! What is up with that. Granted its the only shabu place I know around here in the Bay. Go here if you never shabu before which is basically hot pot but you are hot potting solo. They have some cute decorations around the restaurant which made me want to steal one of those cute little dolls. This is a very hidden spot btw. Parking is alright. Sometimes the bum scare me but yeah this is Fillmore. If you are want to hot pot but don't want to share your broth with others, then come here. Enjoy! Get your sweat on and come out smelling oh so wonderful with a nice stean face.

FG_cmTqI_8CiM_nqGz4lsw.review_text: Terrible food, disgusting and immature clientele that treat this place as a frat house, and an owner who doesn't care about noise levels to his surrounding neighbors because the only business he gets are from 21 year olds on a Saturday night.

xhmZx6LhFdyBbuytKp5MOA.review_text: Bad service. Horrible meat quality. Angry owner. No one wants to be treated with no respect. You don't deserve a tip but you already added it into my bill. Never coming here again.

D2epirooWNjvwTI6MFhNGw.review_text: I was all set and ready to give this place 4 stars but man, this effing horrible service here is a travesty against mankind itself.  I'm undergoing some health issues at the moment that involve blood loss and i've been advised to eat a huge fat steak to make up for the iron and blood loss... so somehow, i ended up here ordering all you can eat beef.  and to top it off, i have to constantly keep eating red meat and salty foods to keep my blood pressure up.   1) the dipping sauces here get salty after awhile. don't mess with that yellow one, its gross. it tastes like burnt peanuts. 2) dont bother trying to get a refill of water or tea, or a second platter of anything when you ordered all you can eat.  3) if you're asian, good luck getting any service. they waitresses seem to LOVE big groups of white people. the entire restaurant was full of asian customers and 1 group of white people. WHO GOT ALL THE ATTENTION? WHO GOT ALL THE SERVICE?? WHOSE BEERS AND SAKES WERE FLOWING ALL NIGHT LONG? WHOSE TABLE WAS NEVER EMPTY OF BEEF, ENOKI MUSHROOMS AND ALL THAT GOODNESS!? shit.. i probably could have bled to death and passed out before they even take my fucking order.
